(b)	It shall be further unlawful for any person operating a poolroom or billiard parlor to allow any person who has not attained the age of 21 years to enter into or participate in any game of pool or billiards or any other game operated in any such poolroom or billiard parlor. It shall be the duty of the operator of a poolroom or billiard parlor to prevent any minor from entering the building in which a poolroom or billiard parlor is operated for the public. 
(Code 1988, § 11-1-3)
Sec. 54-4. - Unauthorized persons on public school grounds or facilities. 
No person shall be allowed on the grounds or in a facility of any city public school unless the person is an employee of the city board of education, a member of the city board of education, a member of the city council, or is specifically authorized to be on those grounds or in that facility by the principal or assistant principal of a school; provided that students shall be allowed on the grounds or in the facility of any city public school only during regular school hours and during after-school hours for authorized school activities. Such authorized school activities shall be those designated by the principal, assistant principal or a teacher of the school. 
(Code 1988, § 11-1-4)
Sec. 54-5. - Loitering or littering in public places. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter in a public park, on a public street, or in a public parking area, or for anyone to litter a public park, public street, or a public parking area. 
(b)	The term "loiter" shall mean being in a public park, on a public street, or in a public parking area at a time or in a manner not usual for law-abiding individuals under circumstances that warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or immediate concern for the safety of persons or property in the vicinity of that area. 
(c)	The term "litter" shall mean the scattering or strewing of trash, garbage, or any discarded items or objects on the public park grounds, on the public streets, or on a public parking area. 
(Code 1988, § 11-1-5)
State Law reference— Authority to proscribe loitering, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-36; littering, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-48. 
Sec. 54-6. - Disorderly conduct. 
It shall be unlawful and disorderly conduct for any person to: 
(1)	Act in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another, whereby a reasonable person would be placed in fear of safety for life or limb; 
(2)	Place the property of another in serious danger of being destroyed or damaged;
(3)	Use fighting words directed toward another, who becomes outraged and thus creates a turmoil; 
(4)	Violently interfere with another's pursuit of a lawful occupation; or
(5)	Congregate with others to halt the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic and refuse to clear the way when ordered by lawful authority to do so. 
(Code 1988, § 11-1-6)
State Law reference— Authority to punish disorderly conduct, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-34. 
Sec. 54-7. - Public drunkenness. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to be and appear in an intoxicated condition on any public property, on private property open to the public, or for any person to occupy the seat or any portion of a motor vehicle upon the public streets of the city while under the influence of intoxicating liquors or drugs, or to be within the curtilage of any private residence not his own, other than by invitation of the owner or lawful occupant. Such condition must be made manifest by boisterousness or by indecent condition or acting or by vulgar, profane or unbecoming language, or loud and violent discourse of the person so intoxicated. 
(Code 1988, § 11-1-7)
State Law reference— Authority to proscribe public drunkenness, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41. 
Sec. 54-8. - Opprobrious and abusive words. 
A person who without provocation, uses to or of another, in his presence, opprobrious or abusive words which by their very utterance tend to incite to an immediate breach of the peace, that is to say, words which as a matter of common knowledge and under ordinary circumstances will, when used to or of another person in his presence, naturally tend to provoke violent resentment, that is, words commonly called "fighting words." 
(Code 1988, § 11-1-8)
State Law reference— Fighting words and incite to act, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-39. 
Sec. 54-9. - Curfew for minors. 
It is unlawful for any minor 16 years of age or younger to loiter, wander, stroll or play in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds or other public grounds, public places, public buildings, places of amusement, eating places, vacant lots, or any place unsupervised by an adult having lawful authority to be at such places between the hours of 12:00 midnight on any day and 6:00 a.m. of the following morning; provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not apply in the following instances: 
(1)	When any such minor is accompanied by his or her parent, guardian, or other adult person having the lawful care and custody of such minor; 
(2)	When any such minor is upon an emergency errand directed by his or her parent, guardian or other adult person having the lawful care and custody of such minor; 
(3)	When any such minor is returning directly home from a scheduled and approved school function, activity or entertainment such as a recreational activity or dance; 
(4)	When any such minor is returning directly home from a place of lawful employment so as to make it necessary for such minor to be in such place of employment during the prescribed period of time; 
(5)	When any such minor is attending or traveling directly to or from an activity involving the exercise of first amendment rights of free speech, freedom of assembly or free exercise of religion; or 
(6)	When any such minor is in a motor vehicle traveling through the city with no intent to stop or sojourn in the city. 
(Code 1988, § 11-1-9)
Sec. 54-10. - Parental responsibility; violation; penalty. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian or other person having custody or control of any child 16 years of age or younger to permit, or by insufficient control or supervision, to allow any such child to be in or upon the public streets or any other place listed in section 54-9 within the city between the hours of 12:00 midnight on any day and 6:00 a.m. the succeeding day except under the circumstances set forth in section 54-9. Upon conviction of violation of this section for the first time, in the discretion of the judge of the municipal court, such person may be given a warning citation. Upon further conviction, a person shall be subject to a fine not to exceed $500.00 and costs, imprisonment in the city jail for not more than 60 days, work on the public streets or on the public works of the city for not more than 60 days or to any one or more of such punishments. Each violation of this section shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)	As an alternative to the penalty provision provided in subsection (a) of this section, the judge of the municipal court of the city may, in his discretion, order any person in violation of the provision of such subsection to attend and participate in, at their expense, an alternative treatment or intervention program recommended and approved by the court. 
(Code 1988, § 11-1-10)
Sec. 54-11. - Disorderly houses. 
It shall be unlawful for any person keep a disorderly house, where noisy or riotous persons assemble to the annoyance of citizens in the neighborhood. 
(Ord. No. 08-11-3-1, § 1, 11-3-2008)
Secs. 54-12—54-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MAINTENANCE OF PROPERTY AND NUISANCES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Abatement of scrap tire nuisance, § 78-74.
State Law reference— Nuisances generally, O.C.G.A. § 41-1-1 et seq.; abatement of nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-1 et seq.; littering control, O.C.G.A. §§ 16-7-43, 16-7-46.

Sec. 54-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Ashes means the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke or other combustible material. 
Garbage means putrescible animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
Refuse means all putrescible or nonputrescible waste (except body waste), including, but not limited to, garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned automobiles and solid market and industrial waste. 
Rubbish means nonputrescible waste (including ashes), consisting of both combustible and noncombustible waste, including, but not limited to, paper, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, wood, glass, bedding, crockery and similar materials. 
Unauthorized accumulation of refuse means refuse which is stored or accumulated on any premises in the city in such manner as to create unsanitary conditions, or to create fire hazards; or to cause offensive and obnoxious odors; or to provide a breeding place for insects or a harboring place for vermin; or to invite plundering; or to endanger the safety of children as well as adults; or to reduce property values; or in any way to adversely affect the health, safety, welfare and well-being of the public. 
(Code 1988, § 11-2-1)
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 54-32. - Containers. 
(a)	Refuse containers shall be provided by the owner, tenant, lessee or occupant of the premises and shall be maintained in good condition. Any container that does not conform to the provisions of this section or that may have ragged or sharp edges or any other defect liable to hamper or injure the person collecting the contents thereof shall be promptly replaced upon notice. 
(b)	Garbage containers shall be made of metal or plastic, equipped with suitable handles and tightfitting covers, and shall be watertight. Garbage containers shall have a capacity of not more than 40 gallons. Paper or plastic bags manufactured specifically for the storage of garbage may be used provided the bags are attached to a bag holder which is equipped with a watertight lid made of durable metal or plastic. Garbage containers shall be kept clean, neat and in a sanitary condition at all times and shall be located on the premises at a place easily accessible to the collectors. Each owner, tenant, lessee or occupant of the premises shall provide an adequate number of garbage containers to hold the amount of garbage accumulated between collections. 
(c)	Rubbish containers shall be of the kind suitable for collection purposes and the location and type shall be approved by the authorized representative of the city. 
(Code 1988, § 11-2-2)
Sec. 54-33. - Scattering refuse. 
(a)	No person shall place refuse in any street, alley or other public place, or upon any private property, whether owned by such person or not within the city except as prescribed in this article. 
(b)	No person shall throw or deposit any refuse in any stream or other body of water.
(c)	No person shall cast, place, sweep or deposit anywhere within the city any refuse in such a manner that it may be carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk, alley, sewer, parkway or other public place, or into any occupied premises within the city. 
(d)	Scattering refuse as provided in this section is declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited. 
(Code 1988, § 11-2-3)
State Law reference— Littering, O.C.G.A. §§ 16-7-43, 16-7-48. 
Sec. 54-34. - Unauthorized accumulations generally; abandoned motor vehicles; motor vehicles parts. 
(a)	Any unauthorized accumulation of refuse on any premises is declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited. Such nuisance shall be abated as prescribed in section 54-39. 
(b)	The accumulation of one or more motor vehicles or any major part thereof which is in any one of the following conditions: 
(1)	Resting on blocks;
(2)	Without wheels;
(3)	With major parts missing;
(4)	Without tires; or
(5)	In a state of repair which precludes further use;
is declared to be an unauthorized accumulation of refuse, except where vehicles are stored in an enclosed building or located on the premises of a licensed business enterprise operated in a lawful place and manner when necessary to the operation of such licensed business enterprise; provided, however, where any such motor vehicle or major part thereof is not located in an enclosed building, such premises shall be screened on all sides by fence and shrubbery so as to shield such accumulation from sight. 
(c)	In addition to the prohibitions stated in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, no vehicles, parts of vehicles, or former vehicles (including, but not limited to, vehicle tires and truck trailers) shall be parked or stored openly. This prohibition shall not apply to vehicles which bear an up-to-date license and for which all ad valorem taxes have been paid. 
(Code 1988, § 11-2-4; Ord. of 11-18-2002; Ord. No. 13-04-15C, § 1, 4-15-2013)
Editor's note— Ord. No. 13-04-15C, § 1, adopted Apr. 15, 2013, retitled the catchline of § 54-34 from "Unauthorized accumulations generally; abandoned motor vehicles" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 54-35. - Unauthorized disposal areas. 
It shall be unlawful to dump, deposit or dispose of any refuse on any lot of record, as defined by section 102-2, public street, alley or roadway within the city, unless an application for the designation of a disposal area showing such use of the area has been authorized by the city. Failure to comply with this section is declared to be a nuisance. The location and boundaries of such disposal areas must be filed in the office of the city manager and must be approved by the city manager prior to use as a disposal area. The city manager shall have the authority to impose restrictions on type of disposal. 
(Code 1988, § 11-2-5)
Sec. 54-36. - Burning leaves; rubbish. 
Leaves, rubbish or refuse of any kind shall not be set on fire or burned on any paved street or sidewalk. 
(Code 1988, § 11-2-6)
Sec. 54-37. - Unsightly or unhealthful growth prohibited. 
No person shall allow or permit weeds, grass and other such vegetable matter to grow and be upon his lot of record, as defined in section 102-2, uncut so as to render the premises unsightly or unhealthful, or so as to constitute a fire hazard, a breeding place for mosquitoes, or cause other peril from the growth and accumulation of such weeds, grass or other vegetable matter. Any such growth in excess of one foot in height shall be deemed to constitute such prohibited condition. 
(Code 1988, § 11-2-7)
Sec. 54-38. - Declaration of nuisance. 
To permit the growth and accumulation of weeds, grass or other vegetable matter so as to create any condition mentioned in section 54-37 is declared to be a nuisance. 
(Code 1988, § 11-2-8)
Sec. 54-39. - Complaint; trial; order to abate nuisance. 
Any nuisance on private property created by the failure of any person to comply with the requirements of sections 54-33—54-38 may be removed on the written complaint of any officer or inhabitant of the city, which complaint must set forth particularly the nature and location of the nuisance and the person complained against. On such complaint being filed with the city clerk, the city clerk shall issue a summons to the person charged with maintaining the nuisance, requiring him to show cause before the municipal judge at some time therein specified, not more than five days off, why the nuisance complained of should not be abated; which notice shall be served by any police officer, on the person complained against at least one day before the hearing, by handing him a copy or leaving the summons at his residence or place of business. At the trial the court shall hear evidence as to the facts and pass such order as may be just. If the thing complained of is a nuisance, the order shall specify within what time it is to be abated by the defendant; or should the municipal judge find that it would be unreasonable to order the nuisance abated under the facts presented to him, he may order that the person charged with maintaining the nuisance shall within 30 days from the date of the hearing go before the mayor and council at either a regular or called meeting and petition the council to remove a portion or all of the lot complained of from the provisions of this section. If the council, by a majority vote, elects to remove a portion or all of the petitioner's lot of record from the provision of this section, the nuisance shall be abated only on any portion that remains within a time set by the municipal judge at the hearing. If it is not abated within the time specified in the order, the clerk shall issue a writ directed to the chief of police, directing and requiring the abatement of the nuisance. 
(Code 1988, § 11-2-9)
Sec. 54-40. - Collection of abatement expense. 
Whenever the person creating or maintaining any nuisance within the city shall fail to abate after notice to do so, and it shall become necessary to issue a writ, directed to the chief of police, requiring him to remove the nuisance, it shall be the duty of the chief of police to keep an account of the necessary expenses incurred and to render to the clerk a statement of those expenses. The clerk shall issue execution against the owner for that amount, which execution shall be levied upon and collected in the same manner as is provided for the levy and collection of executions for taxes. 
(Code 1988, § 11-2-10)
Sec. 54-41. - Unsightly conditions in residential areas. 
(a)	No person shall maintain residential property in which such person is residing in an unsightly condition. The term "unsightly condition" shall include, but is not limited to, unkept yards, porches, steps or stoops and the cluttering of yards, porches, steps or stoops with any items which would detract from or have any adverse effect on the aesthetics of the neighborhood. 
(b)	Any person convicted of violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-7. 
(Ord. of 9-18-95)
Sec. 54-42. - Penalties for violation. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction in the municipal court of the city, be punished as provided in section 1-7. 
Secs. 54-43—54-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - COMMERCIAL SOLICITATION 

Sec. 54-50. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them: 
Commercial solicitation or to commercially solicit means any request made in person without a permit, asking for an immediate donation of money or other thing of value, including the purchase of an item or service for an amount far exceeding its value, under circumstances in which a reasonable person would understand that the purchase is a donation. "Commercial solicitation" shall include passively standing or sitting with a sign or other indication that one is seeking donations without addressing the request to any specific person. 
Downtown development area means the area as designated by the City of Hogansville in conjunction with its activation of the Downtown Development Authority of the City of Hogansville, which area is specifically described within "Exhibit A," attached to Ordinance No. 13-04-15D, and is generally described as follows: 
That area of the City of Hogansville bounded on the south by East Boyd Road and Boyd Road; bounded on the west by Pine Street, Ware Street and the railroad right of way; bounded on the north by Green Avenue and Lincoln Street; and bounded on the east by Industrial Drive. 
Highway 54 commercial corridor means that area of Highway 54 from the downtown development area running east to the termination of the city limits, as well as 500 feet on both sides of Highway 54. 
(Ord. No. 13-04-15D, § 1, 4-15-2013)
Sec. 54-51. - Certain commercial solicitation prohibited; area of restriction. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to commercially solicit when the person solicited is in any of the following places within the City of Hogansville, unless otherwise provided for in section 54-52 below: 
(1)	On private property if the owner, tenant or lawful occupant has asked the person not to solicit on the property, or has posted a sign clearly indicating that solicitations are not welcome on the property; 
(2)	Within the streets, sidewalks or other public areas of the Downtown development area and Highway 54 commercial corridor as defined in section 54-50 above. 
(Ord. No. 13-04-15D, § 1, 4-15-2013)
Sec. 54-52. - Exceptions. 
The following persons are exempt from the provisions of this article which ban commercial solicitation: 
(1)	Educational institutions and those organizations, foundations, associations, corporations, charities and agencies operated, supervised or controlled by or in connection with a nonprofit educational institution, provided that any such institutional organization is qualified under Section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended; 
(2)	Fraternal, civic, benevolent, patriotic and social organizations, when solicitation of contributions is carried on by persons without any form of compensation and which solicitation is confined to their membership; 
(3)	Any charitable organization whose total gross revenue has been less than $25,000.00 for both the immediately preceding and current calendar years; 
(4)	Religious organizations; and
(5)	Political parties, candidates for federal or state office, and political action committees required to file financial information with federal or state elections commissions. 
(Ord. No. 13-04-15D, § 1, 4-15-2013)
Sec. 54-53. - Permit required. 
(a)	No person shall engage in commercial solicitation pursuant to this article unless a permit shall have been obtained from the city manager or his designee. An application for a commercial solicitation permit shall be made to the city manager at least two weeks prior to the proposed date(s) of the commercial solicitation and shall contain all necessary information relating to the same including but in no way limited to: 
(1)	The name of person sponsoring and/or conducting the commercial solicitation;
(2)	The purpose of the commercial solicitation;
(3)	The date and beginning and ending hours of the commercial solicitation;
(4)	The location(s) within the City of Hogansville of the proposed commercial solicitation;
(5)	The estimated number of participants expected to engage in the commercial solicitation; and 
(6)	The name, address and telephone number of a contact person with the sponsor of the commercial solicitation who will be familiar with all aspects of same. 
(b)	Written approval or denial of the application for commercial solicitation permits shall be issued by the city manager within seven days of the filing of the application. Any person denied a permit or who disagrees with the restrictions placed on the permit may appeal such decision to the next regular meeting of the mayor and council. There shall be no cost for the permit. 
(c)	The city manager shall receive and investigate all applications for commercial solicitation permits and is authorized to issue such permits based on the information contained in the application, provided the commercial solicitation is otherwise lawful and when, in the discretion of the city manager, the proposed solicitation will allow for proper traffic control and pedestrian safety. The city manager shall have the right to impose reasonable restrictions on the solicitation including the date, hours, location and number of participants when, in his judgment, such reasonable restrictions are necessary or desirable for the safety, protection and welfare of the public. 
(Ord. No. 13-04-15D, § 1, 4-15-2013)
Sec. 54-54. - Penalties. 
Any person who shall violate the provisions of this ordinance shall upon conviction in the municipal court of the city be punished as provided in Code section 1-7. 
(Ord. No. 13-04-15D, § 1, 4-15-2013)
Chapter 62 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 18; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82.
State Law reference— Charitable Solicitations Act of 1988, O.C.G.A. § 43-17-1 et seq.; Transient Merchant Act of Georgia, O.C.G.A. § 43-46-1 et seq.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 62-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Peddler means any person, whether a resident of the city or not, traveling by foot, wagon, automotive vehicle, or any other type of conveyance from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, carrying, conveying, or transporting goods, wares, merchandise, or provisions, and who offers and exposes such goods, wares or merchandise for sale from a wagon, automotive vehicle, railroad car, or other vehicle or conveyance. 
Itinerant merchant means any person, whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, and whether a resident of the city or not, who engages in a temporary business of selling and delivering goods, wares and merchandise within the city, and who, in furtherance of such purposes, hires, leases, uses, or occupies any building, structure, motor vehicle, tent, railroad boxcar, boat, or public room in any hotel, lodginghouse, apartment, or shop within the city for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares, and merchandise, either privately or at public auction. 
(Code 1988, § 9-5-1)
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 62-2—62-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PEDDLERS AND ITINERANT MERCHANTS 

Sec. 62-31. - License required. 
Each peddler and itinerant merchant who does business within the city shall obtain a license from the city clerk in the manner specified in this chapter. 
(Code 1988, § 9-5-2)
Sec. 62-32. - Exemptions. 
The license required by this article shall not be applicable to traveling salesmen of nonresident merchants, nor to newsboys, nor to bona fide merchants who merely deliver goods in the regular course of business, nor to bona fide charitable, religious, or philanthropic organizations, nor to nonresident merchants selling through licensed flea markets. 
(Code 1988, § 9-5-3)
Sec. 62-33. - Application for license. 
Application for a license shall be made as provided in section 18-34, except that the application shall contain the following additional information: 
(1)	The fingerprints of the person having the management or supervision of the applicant's business, or in lieu thereof, at least three letters of recommendation from reliable property owners in the county in which the business is to be conducted, certifying as to the applicant's good character and business responsibility, or other evidence which establishes the good character and business responsibility of that person to the satisfaction of the city manager; 
(2)	The place or places in the city where it is proposed to carry on the applicant's business, and the length of time during which it is proposed that the business shall be conducted; 
(3)	The place or places, other than the permanent place of business of the applicant, where the applicant within the six months next preceding the date of the application conducted a transient business, stating the nature thereof and giving the post office and street address of any building or office in which such business was conducted; 
(4)	A statement of the nature, character, and quality of the goods, wares or merchandise to be sold or offered for sale by the applicant in the city; the invoice value and quality of such goods, wares and merchandise; where the goods or property to be sold are manufactured or produced; and where such goods or products are located at the time such application is filed; 
(5)	A brief statement of the nature and character of the advertising done in order to attract customers; and, if required by the city manager, copies of all advertising, whether by handbills, circulars, newspaper advertising, or otherwise, shall be attached to the application; and 
(6)	Whether or not the person having the management or supervision of the applicant's business has been convicted of a crime, misdemeanor, or the violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of such offense, and punishment assessed therefor. 
(Code 1988, § 9-5-4)
Sec. 62-34. - Bond. 
Before any license shall be issued for engaging in a transient or itinerant business as provided in this article, the applicant for the license shall file with the city clerk a bond running to the city in the sum of $2,000.00, executed by the applicant, as principal, and two sureties upon which service of process may be made in the state. Such bond shall be approved by the city attorney, conditioned that the applicant shall comply fully with all of the provisions of the ordinances of the city and the statutes of the state regulating and concerning the sale of goods, wares and merchandise, and will pay all judgments rendered against the applicant for any violation of those ordinances or statutes, or any of them, together with all judgments and costs that may be recovered against him by any person for damage growing out of any misrepresentation or deception practiced on any person transacting such business with the applicant, whether the misrepresentations or deceptions made were practiced by the owners or by their servants, agents or employees, either at the time of making the sale or through any advertisement of any character whatsoever, printed or circulated with references to the goods, wares and merchandise sold or any part thereof. Action on the bond may be brought in the name of the city to the use of the aggrieved person. Such bond must be approved by the city attorney, both as to form and as to the responsibility of the sureties thereon. 
(Code 1988, § 9-5-5)
Sec. 62-35. - Service of process. 
Before any license shall be issued for engaging in business as a peddler or itinerant merchant, the applicant shall file with the city clerk an instrument nominating and appointing the city clerk his true and lawful agent with full power and authority to acknowledge service of notice of process for and on behalf of the applicant in respect to any matters connected with or arising out of the business transacted under the license and the bond given as required by this article, or for the performance of the conditions of the bond, or for any breach thereof, which instrument shall also contain recitals to the effect that the applicant for the license consents and agrees that service of any notice or process may be made upon the agent, and when so made shall be taken and held to be as valid as if personally served upon the person applying for the license, and waiving all claim or right of error by reason of such acknowledgement of service or manner of service. Immediately upon service of process upon the city clerk, as provided in this section, the city clerk shall send to the licensee at his last known address, by registered mail, a copy of that process. 
(Code 1988, § 9-5-6)
Sec. 62-36. - Fee established. 
The business license fee for each peddler and itinerant merchant doing business in the city shall be as fixed from time to time by the city council. 
(Code 1988, § 9-5-7)
Sec. 62-37. - Loud noises and speaking devices. 
No licensee, nor anyone in his behalf, shall shout, make any outcry, blow a horn, ring a bell, or use any other sound device including any loudspeaker or amplifying system upon any of the streets, alleys, parks, or other public places of the city or upon any private premises in the city where sound of sufficient volume is emitted or produced therefrom capable of being plainly heard upon the streets, avenues, alleys, parks or other public places for the purpose of attracting attention to any goods, wares or merchandise which the licensee proposes to sell. 
(Code 1988, § 9-5-8)
Secs. 62-38—62-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Georgia Charitable Solicitations Act of 1988, O.C.G.A. § 43-17-1 et seq.; municipality authorized to adopt additional regulations, O.C.G.A. § 43-17-17.

Sec. 62-61. - Registration required. 
Any person who wishes to solicit donations or contributions for, or sell any insignia or novelty on the streets of the city on behalf of, or under the sponsorship of, any charitable, religious, social, patriotic, or civic club or organization shall be required to register such solicitation or sale with the city clerk at least 48 hours in advance of such event and to obtain a permit for such solicitation. 
(Code 1988, § 9-5-21)
Sec. 62-62. - Form of registration. 
The registration required by this division shall be in writing, shall be signed by the chief officer of the club or organization, and shall contain the following information: 
(1)	The name and object of the charitable, religious, social, patriotic or civic club or organization conducting or sponsoring the solicitation or sale to which the registration relates; 
(2)	The day or days on which the solicitation or sale will take place;
(3)	The object for which the funds to be derived from the solicitation or sale will be utilized; and 
(4)	The name and address of the chief officer of the club or organization conducting or sponsoring the solicitation or sale. 
(Code 1988, § 9-5-22)
Sec. 62-63. - Exemption. 
This article shall not apply to any local established organization or church operated exclusively for charitable or religious purposes if the solicitations are in the form of collections or contributions at the regular assemblies of any such organization or church. 
(Code 1988, § 9-5-23)
Sec. 62-64. - Duty to exhibit permit. 
Charitable solicitors shall exhibit their permits at the request of any citizen. 
(Code 1988, § 9-5-24)
Sec. 62-65. - Unlawful acts. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to submit a registration which contains any false statement. It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit donations or contributions or sell any insignia or novelty on the streets of the city purportedly on behalf of, or under the sponsorship of, any charitable, religious, social, patriotic or civic club or organization which does not in fact exist. 
(Code 1988, § 9-5-25)
Sec. 62-66. - Penalties for violation. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this division shall, upon conviction in the municipal court of the city, be punished as provided in section 1-7. 
Chapter 66 - PERSONNEL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; law enforcement, ch. 50.
State Law reference— Municipality personnel system, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III; personnel benefits authorized, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-4; employee benefits, O.C.G.A. § 47-5-1 et seq.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 66-1. - General purpose. 
The general purpose of this chapter is to establish a system of personnel administration that meets the social, economic and program needs of the people of the city. This system shall provide means to recruit, select, develop and maintain an effective and responsible work force, and shall include policies and procedures for employee hiring and advancement, training and career development, job classifications, salary administration, retirement, fringe benefits, discharge and other related activities. All appointments and promotions in the city service shall be made without regard to sex, race, religion or political affiliation, and shall be based on merit and fitness. 
(Code 1988, § 2-4-11)
Sec. 66-2. - Career service. 
(a)	The career service shall be a permanent service to which this law shall apply and shall comprise all tenured positions in the public service now existing or hereafter established, except the following: 
(1)	The mayor and members of the city council;
(2)	Members of boards and commissions, the city manager, and the city attorney;
(3)	Persons employed to make or conduct a temporary and special inquiry, investigation, or examination on behalf of the council, a committee thereof, or the city manager; 
(4)	Part-time or temporary positions unless specifically covered by action of the city manager or council. 
(b)	Nothing in this section shall be construed as precluding the appointing authority from filling any position in the manner in which positions in the career service are filled. 
(Code 1988, § 2-4-12)
Sec. 66-3. - Administration. 
(a)	There shall be a personnel department in the city, the executive head of which shall be the city manager or other person designated by Charter or the council. In carrying out his duties as personnel director, he may designate any member of his staff to assist him. 
(b)	The city manager is executive head of the personnel department and shall direct all of its administrative and technical activities and appoint its employees. It shall be the duty of the city manager to: 
(1)	Encourage and exercise leadership in the development of effective personnel administration within the several departments in the government service, and to make available the facilities of the personnel department to this end; 
(2)	Advise the city council on manpower utilization;
(3)	Foster and develop programs for the improvement of employee effectiveness;
(4)	Investigate from time to time the operation and effect of this chapter and of the policies made under this chapter and to report his findings and recommendations to the council; 
(5)	Establish and maintain records of all employees in the government service, in which there shall be set forth as to each employee the class, title, pay or status and other relevant data; 
(6)	Make an annual report to the council regarding the work of the department; and
(7)	Apply and carry out this chapter and the policies under this chapter and to perform any other lawful acts which may be necessary or desirable to carry out the purposes and provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1988, § 2-4-13)
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. 
Sec. 66-4. - Personnel policies. 
The city manager or a consultant empowered by the city council shall draft personnel policies for the city. Adequate public notice of proposed personnel policies, or additions or changes therein, shall be given to all interested parties. All proposed regulations shall be submitted to the city council for their review and approval by resolution. The policies shall provide: 
(1)	For the preparation, maintenance and revision of a position classification plan for all positions in the career service, based upon similarity of duties performed and responsibilities assumed, so that the same qualifications may reasonably be required for, and the same schedule of pay may be equitably applied to, all positions in the same class. After such classification plan has been approved by the city council, the personnel director shall allocate or reallocate the position of every employee in the career service to one of the classes in the plan. Any employee affected by the allocation or reallocation of a position to a class, shall, after filing with the city manager a written request for reconsideration thereof in such manner and form as the city manager may prescribe, be given a reasonable opportunity to be heard thereon. 
(2)	For the annual submission of a pay plan to the city council.
(3)	For recruitment of capable persons and for administering fair open evaluations, to determine the relative fitness of applicants for positions in the public service. 
(4)	For the certification to the appointing authority of the names of persons who are categorized as qualified to fill a vacancy. 
(5)	For the establishment and maintenance of eligible lists for appointment and promotion, upon which lists shall be placed the names of successful candidates. 
(6)	For promotions which shall give appropriate consideration to the applicant's qualifications, record of performance and ability. 
(7)	For a period of employee probation, upon appointment or promotion, not to exceed one year, prior to permanent appointment. 
(8)	For emergency employment for not more than 90 days with the consent of the city manager and for provisional employment without open evaluation when there is no appropriate eligible list available. No such provisional employment shall continue longer than six months nor shall successive provisional appointments be allowed except during the first year after the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter was derived. 
(9)	For the establishment of programs, including trainee programs, designed to attract and utilize persons with minimal qualifications, but with potential for development, in order to provide career development opportunities among members of disadvantaged groups, handicapped persons and returning veterans. Such programs may provide for permanent appointment upon the satisfactory completion of the training period without further examination. 
(10)	For keeping records of performance of all employees in the career service, which performance records shall be considered in determining salary increments or increases for meritorious service; as a factor in promotions; as a factor in determining the order of layoffs because of lack of funds or work and in reinstatement; and as a factor in demotions, discharges and transfers. 
(11)	For layoffs by reason of lack of funds or work or abolition of a position, or material change in duties or organization, and for reemployment of employees so laid off. 
(12)	For establishment of a plan for resolving employee grievances and complaints.
(13)	For establishment of disciplinary measures such as suspension, demotion in rank or grade, or discharge. Such measures shall provide for presentation of charges, hearing rights, and appeals for all permanent employees in the career service. 
(14)	For establishing and publicizing fringe benefits such as insurance programs, retirement and leave policies. 
(15)	For establishing hours of work, holidays and attendance regulations in various classes of positions in the career service. 
(16)	For development and operation of programs to improve work effectiveness including training, safety, health, welfare, counseling, recreation and employee relations. 
(17)	For such other policies and administrative regulations, not inconsistent with this chapter as may be proper and necessary for its enforcement. 
(Code 1988, § 2-4-14)
Sec. 66-5. - Certification of payroll. 
The city manager or his authorized agent shall be responsible for certification of the payroll vouchers that the persons named therein have been appointed and employed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and the policies under this chapter. No city disbursing or auditing officer shall make or approve or take any part in making or approving any payment for personal service to any persons holding a position in the city government unless the payroll voucher or account of such pay bears the certification of the city manager or his authorized agent. 
(Code 1988, § 2-4-15)
Sec. 66-6. - Grievance procedure. 
(a)	A grievance is any dispute concerning the interpretation or application of this chapter, or of the personnel policies governing personnel practices or working conditions, or decisions relative to any disciplinary action, dismissal, demotion or charge of discrimination. 
(b)	Grievances shall be processed in accordance with procedures established by the city council in personnel policies. 
(c)	An appeals board is hereby created, the chair of which shall be the mayor. The chair shall be empowered to select necessary councilmembers in cases where needed to complete the appeals board. The appeals board shall have the power to settle grievances and in more serious cases to review and recommend attention to the city council. 
(Code 1988, § 2-4-16)
Sec. 66-7. - Agreements authorized. 
(a)	The city is authorized and empowered to enter into reciprocal agreements, upon such terms as may be agreed upon, for the use of equipment, materials, facilities and services with any public agency or body for purposes deemed of benefit to the public personnel system. 
(b)	The city manager, acting in behalf of the city council, may cooperate with other governmental agencies charged with public personnel administration in conducting personnel tests, recruiting personnel, training personnel, establishing lists from which eligibles shall be certified for appointments and for the interchange of personnel and their benefits. 
(Code 1988, § 2-4-17)
Sec. 66-8. - Political activities. 
(a)	No city employee in the career service shall hold an elective office in the city government, nor shall he give or solicit any contributions or assessments, or services, nor publicly endorse any candidate for any city elective office. 
(b)	Nothing contained in this chapter shall affect the right of an employee to contribute to, hold membership in, serve as an officer of, or support a political party, to vote as he chooses, to support or campaign for county, state, or national political candidates, to express privately his opinions on all political subjects and candidates, to maintain political neutrality or to attend political meetings. 
(c)	Any city employee who, as a normal and foreseeable incident to his principal job or position, performs duties in connection with an activity financed in whole or in part by federal loans or grants, comes under the Federal Hatch Act which prohibits the following: 
(1)	Use of official authority or influence for the purpose of interfering with an election or nomination for office, or affecting the result thereof; 
(2)	Directly or indirectly coercing, attempting to coerce, commanding or advising any other officer or employee to pay, lend, or contribute any part of his salary or compensation or anything else of value to any party; committee, organization, agency, or person for political purposes; 
(3)	Active participation in political management or in political campaigns.
(Code 1988, § 2-4-18)
Sec. 66-9. - Unlawful acts prohibited. 
(a)	No person shall make any false statement, certificate, mark, rating or report with regard to any test, certification or appointment made under any provision of this chapter or in any manner commit or attempt to commit any fraud preventing the impartial execution of this chapter and policies of this chapter. 
(b)	No person shall, directly or indirectly give, render, pay, offer, solicit, or accept any money, service, or other valuable consideration for any appointment, proposed appointment, promotion, or proposed promotion to, or any advantage in, a position in the career service. 
(c)	No employee of the personnel department, examiner, or other person shall defeat, deceive or obstruct any person in his right to examination, eligibility, certification or appointment under this chapter, or furnish to any person any special or secret information for the purpose of affecting the rights or prospects of any person with respect to employment in the career service. 
(Code 1988, § 2-4-19)
Secs. 66-10—66-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SOCIAL SECURITY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Georgia Benefit System, O.C.G.A. § 47-5-20.

Sec. 66-31. - Coverage extended. 
It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend at the earliest date possible under the agreement entered into by the state and the Federal Security Administrator, to the employees and officials thereof, and its instrumentalities, not excluded by law or by this article, the benefits of the Federal Social Security Act and amendments thereto. In pursuance of such policy, and for that purpose, the city shall take such action as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1988, § 2-4-31)
Sec. 66-32. - Agreements. 
The mayor or other chief executive officer of the city is hereby authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the employees' retirement system and officials as provided for in section 66-31. 
(Code 1988, § 2-4-32)
Sec. 66-33. - Employee contributions. 
Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees and officials for the purpose provided in section 66-31 are hereby authorized to be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the state agency. 
(Code 1988, § 2-4-33)
Sec. 66-34. - Contributions by city. 
There shall be appropriated from general funds such amounts at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations for employers' contributions, administrative expenses, and a guaranty fund to assure that the state will not incur any debt or loss as a result of the agreement referred to in section 66-32. Such funds shall be paid over to the employees' retirement system of the state in accordance with regulations established by that agency. 
(Code 1988, § 2-4-34)
Sec. 66-35. - Records; reports. 
The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1988, § 2-4-35)
Sec. 66-36. - Excluded persons. 
(a)	There is hereby excluded from this article any authority to make any agreement with respect to any position or any employee or official now covered, or authorized to be covered, by any other ordinance or law creating any retirement system for any employee or official of the city or its instrumentalities. 
(b)	There is hereby excluded from this article any authority to make any agreement with respect to any position, or any employee or official not authorized to be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1988, § 2-4-36)
Secs. 66-37—66-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PENALTIES 

Sec. 66-61. - Penalties. 
Any person who willfully violates any provision of this chapter or of the personnel policies established under this chapter may, upon hearing by the city council, have one of the following judgments rendered: 
(1)	Dismissal from government service;
(2)	Demotion in rank or grade;
(3)	Ineligibility for appointment to or employment in a position in the city service for a period of time or indefinitely; 
(4)	Suspension for a period of time up to two weeks, as stipulated by the city manager.
(Code 1988, § 9-5-20)
Chapter 70 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; environment, ch. 34; flood damage prevention, ch. 42; historical preservation, ch. 46; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82; subdivisions, ch. 86; PUD, planned unit development district, § 86-291 et seq.; utilities, ch. 98; zoning, ch. 102.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 70-1—70-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL PLANNING COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2.

Sec. 70-31. - Creation. 
In order to guide and accomplish a coordinated and harmonious development of the city which will, in accordance with existing and future needs, best promote the public health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity, and the general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development, the planning commission is hereby created and established. 
(Code 1988, § 8-1-1)
Sec. 70-32. - Membership. 
The planning commission shall consist of eight members, who shall be residents of the city, appointed by the city council. The terms of the members of the planning commission shall be for four years, which terms shall be staggered. Any vacancy in membership of the planning commission shall be filled for the unexpired term by the city council which shall also have the authority to remove any member for cause, on written charges, after a public hearing. All members shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. 
(Code 1988, § 8-1-2)
Sec. 70-33. - Organization; rules, staff; finances. 
(a)	The planning commission shall elect its chair from among its members. The term of the chair shall be one year with eligibility for reelection. The planning commission shall appoint a secretary, who may be an officer or employee of the city. The planning commission shall make its own rules of procedure and determine its time of meeting. All meetings of the planning commission, unless otherwise exempted by law, shall be open to the public. All records of the planning commission shall be a public record. 
(b)	The planning commission may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its work and may contract with the federal, state, or local public or semipublic agencies and other consultants for such services as it may require. The expenditures of the planning commission, exclusive of gifts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for that purpose by the city council. 
(Code 1988, § 8-1-3)
Sec. 70-34. - Powers and duties. 
It shall be the function and duty of the planning commission to make such careful and comprehensive surveys and studies, or participate with agencies in making those surveys and studies, of existing conditions and probable future development and to prepare such plans for physical, social and economic growth as will best promote the public welfare and prosperity, as well as the efficiency and economy in the development of the entire area of the city. In particular, the planning commission shall have the power and duty to: 
(1)	Prepare a master plan or parts thereof for the development of the city;
(2)	Prepare and recommend for adoption to the city council a zoning ordinance and map for the city; 
(3)	Prepare and recommend for adoption by the city council regulations for the subdivision of land, and administer the regulations that may be adopted; and 
(4)	Prepare and recommend for adoption to the city council a plan or official map showing the exact location of the boundary lines of existing, proposed, extended, widened or narrowed streets, public open spaces or public building sites, together with regulations to control the erection of buildings or other structures within such lines, within the city. 
(Code 1988, § 8-1-4)
Secs. 70-35—70-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CITY-COUNTY PLANNING COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2.

Sec. 70-61. - Creation. 
There is hereby created the planning and development commission of Hogansville, LaGrange, West Point, and Troup County. 
(Code 1988, § 8-1-11)
Sec. 70-62. - Membership. 
The membership of the planning and development commission shall consist of five members appointed by the City of LaGrange, four members appointed by the Board of Commissioners of Troup County, three members each appointed by the cities of Hogansville and West Point. All members so appointed to the commission must be residents of Troup County and/or residents of West Point, Hogansville and LaGrange, Georgia. Any expert or other employees need not be residents of the county. 
(Code 1988, § 8-1-12)
Sec. 70-63. - Appropriations. 
There is hereby designated from city funds such sums as appropriated from time to time by the city council to the use of the planning and development commission. 
(Code 1988, § 8-1-13)
Chapter 74 - SIGNS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; signs for sexually oriented businesses, § 18-176; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82; zoning, ch. 102.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 74-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Ground sign means any permanent or temporary sign supported by uprights or braces placed upon the ground, not supported by or suspended from any building. 
Projecting sign means any sign which is attached perpendicular to a building or other structure and extended from the plane of such building walls. 
Public property means any street, alley, sidewalk or other public thoroughfare in the city. 
Separate use sign means a sign advertising a product or service which is offered other than on the premises where the sign is located. 
Sign means any representation with letters, numerals or pictures, graphic, or advertising display including, but not limited to, any announcement, declaration, demonstration or insignia used to advertise or promote the interest of any person. 
Wall sign means any sign which is attached flat to, painted on, or pinned away from the parallel to a wall. 
(Code 1988, § 8-4-2)
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 74-2. - Signs extending over public property—Prohibited. 
No wall sign or projecting sign shall extend more than 18 inches over or onto public property and no ground sign shall extend over public property to any extent. 
(Code 1988, § 8-4-3)
Sec. 74-3. - Same—Restrictions. 
Any ground sign which shall extend over public property and any wall or projecting sign which shall extend over public property more than 18 inches is hereby declared to be a nonconforming sign and can only be maintained, repaired or restored. Such sign must be removed or changed or altered to conform with the provisions of this chapter, in accordance with the terms of this chapter. 
(Code 1988, § 8-4-4)
Sec. 74-4. - Separate use signs; location restrictions. 
Separate use signs are permitted within the city limit area along Highway I-85, SR 403, SR 14, SR 54, and SR 100 where zoned commercial or industrial. 
(Code 1988, § 8-4-5)
Sec. 74-4.1. - Billboards permitted in light industrial district. 
(a)	Billboards shall be allowed in light industrial districts. "Light industrial district" is defined as to provide areas for light manufacturing uses that primarily involve finishing or assembly of previously manufactured goods. The district is also intended to provide for location of wholesale use as well as other uses. 
(1)	Light industrial district excludes manufacturing or industrial uses that emit noxious fumes, odors, dust, gas noise or vibration outside of any building on the premises. It also excludes hazardous materials such as those involving bulk storage of gasoline or toxic chemicals. 
(2)	The district is designed for industrial and warehousing uses that do not have detrimental effect on adjoining residential or commercial developments. 
(b)	Billboards will require a building permit; permit fee will be based on cost of construction. The permit application will require structural drawings sealed by a professional engineer. 
(Ord. No. 05-03-07, 3-7-2005)
Sec. 74-5. - Traffic hazards. 
No sign or other advertising structure shall be erected at the intersection of any street in such a manner as to obstruct the free and clear vision, or at any location where by reason of the position, shape or color thereof, such sign may interfere with, obstruct the view of, or be confused with any authorized traffic sign, signal, or device, or which makes use of the words "Stop," "Look," "Danger," or any other word, phrase, symbol or character so as to interfere with, mislead or confuse traffic. 
(Code 1988, § 8-4-6)
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 94. 
Sec. 74-6. - Obscene signs. 
No person shall use any sign to advertise any obscene, indecent or immoral matter, nor shall any such obscene, indecent or immoral matter be used in or upon such sign. 
(Code 1988, § 8-4-7)
State Law reference— Obscene material defined, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-80; restriction on outdoor signs, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-75. 
Sec. 74-7. - Nonconforming signs; removal. 
Nonconforming signs, signs which on the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter was derived do not conform with the requirements of this chapter, must be removed, changed, or altered to conform with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1988, § 8-4-8)
Sec. 74-8. - Maintenance of nonconforming signs. 
Minor maintenance and repairs of nonconforming signs such as repainting and electrical repairs shall be permitted but changes in the size or shape of the sign shall not be permitted except to make the sign comply with the requirements of this chapter. 
(Code 1988, § 8-4-9)
Sec. 74-9. - Penalties. 
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-7. 
(Code 1988, § 8-4-10)
Sec. 74-10. - Remedies. 
Notwithstanding any other provisions contained in this chapter and for the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter, the building inspector or other appropriate official of the city shall have the right to seek and undertake the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter in the superior court of the county, such right of enforcement being in addition to and cumulative of the enforcement provisions contained in section 74-9, including but not limited to a right to compel demolition of any such nonconforming sign and to enjoin the owner of such sign from the continued maintenance of any such sign, and to enjoin the erection of a sign which does not conform to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1988, § 8-4-11)
Secs. 74-11—74-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - INTERSTATE SIGNS 

Sec. 74-31. - General sign provisions. 
(a)	This article shall apply to all outdoor advertising signs abutting or visible from the Interstate 85 right-of-way in the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)	No sign shall be erected or maintained unless it is in compliance with the regulations of this article. 
(c)	Signs must be constructed of durable materials, maintained in good condition, and not permitted to become dilapidated. 
(d)	All signs located on sites abutting or visible from the Interstate 85 right-of-way shall conform with O.C.G.A. § 32-6-70 et seq. (The Georgia Outdoor Advertising Code) and shall meet all federal and state requirements necessary to obtain a permit under that code. In instances where the sign controls of this article are more strict, the regulations of this article shall apply. 
(e)	Any sign which advertises an activity, business, product or service which has ceased operation or production shall be removed within six months of the discontinuance of that activity, business, product or service. 
(Code 1988, § 8-4-21)
Sec. 74-32. - Prohibited signs. 
(a)	Signs imitating warning signals are prohibited. No sign shall display lights resembling the flashing lights customarily used in traffic signals or in police, fire, ambulance or rescue vehicles; nor shall any signs use the words, slogans, dimensional shapes and sizes, or colors of governmental traffic signs. 
(b)	No signs, except traffic signs and signals and informational signs erected by a public agency, are permitted within any street or highway right-of-way. 
(c)	Signs painted or attached to natural features such as trees or rocks, telephone poles, utility poles, or fence posts are prohibited. 
(d)	Fluttering ribbons and banners are prohibited.
(e)	Signs within 300 feet of any officially designated historical site or monument, except signs pertaining to that particular site or monument, are prohibited. 
(Code 1988, § 8-4-22)
State Law reference— Designated signs, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-73. 
Sec. 74-33. - Regulations for specific types of signs. 
(a)	Home occupation signs. For home occupation signs, one nonilluminated professional or business name plate not exceeding two square feet in area is permitted. 
(b)	Signs of work under construction. For signs of work under construction, one nonilluminated sign not exceeding 40 square feet in area displaying the name of the building, the contractors, the architects, the engineers, the owners, the financial selling and development agencies is permitted upon the premises or any work under construction, alteration, or removal. Such signs shall be removed from the site within 30 days after completion of the project. 
(c)	Temporary subdivision signs. Temporary signs, not exceeding 40 square feet in area, announcing a land subdivision development are permitted on the premises of the land subdivision. Such signs shall be spaced not less than 300 feet apart. Such signs shall be removed when 75 percent of the lots are conveyed. 
(d)	Roof signs. Not more than one roof sign structure may be erected on the roof of any one building. No roof sign structure shall extend more than 25 feet above the elevation of the roof. 
(e)	Wall signs. Signs on the walls of a building, including signs attached flat against the wall, painted wall signs and projecting signs, shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)	Signs on the broad surface of a building. The total area of signs on the exterior surface of a building shall not exceed 25 percent of the front surface of a building. 
(2)	Signs on the side and roof surface of a building. The total area of signs on a side or roof surface of a building shall not exceed 50 percent of the exterior side or roof surface of a building, respectively. 
(3)	Projecting signs. Wall signs attached flat against a wall may extend not more than 24 inches from a wall. Signs attached at an angle to a wall may extend from the wall of a building not more than five feet. 
(f)	Illuminated signs. Illumination devices shall be so placed and so shielded that light from the sign itself will not be directly cast into any residential district, sleeping rooms in any district or the eyes of an automobile or vehicular driver. 
(g)	Outdoor advertising signs. Outdoor advertising signs shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)	Uniform size. The outside measurements of all outdoor advertising signs shall be 12 feet in height and 50 feet in length, with or without trim, or such other measurements as approved by the state department of transportation. 
(2)	Illumination. All illuminated signs shall use base mounted fluorescent or mercury vapor lights and shall be activated by photoelectric cells. Additional lighting, including but not limited to neon, animation and running lights, is prohibited. 
(3)	Height above interstate grade. All signs shall be a minimum of ten feet above adjacent interstate pavement measuring from the lower portion of the sign face. Signs shall not exceed 30 feet in height. Two signs in the same location (back to back or "V" formation) shall be the same height above the interstate's surface. 
(4)	Extrusions prohibited. Extrusions beyond the face of the sign, excluding aprons, are prohibited. 
(5)	Number of signs per location. Only one sign shall be allowed to face the same direction per location. This allows back to back or "V" formation signs but prohibits two signs (side by side) facing the same direction. 
(6)	Spacing. Sign locations shall be no less than 500 feet apart measuring from the two closest points. 
(7)	Number near interchanges. Three outdoor advertising signs are allowed per quadrant of any interchange adjacent to the interstate highway. These signs must be within commercially or industrially zoned areas as specified in state law and are restricted to any area 1,200 feet long beginning 500 feet from the point where the pavement widens on the main traveled way to accommodate the longest entrance or exit ramp. 
(8)	Marsh and historic area locations prohibited. No sign shall be placed in or obstruct the view of a marshland area or any area of designated historic interest. 
(9)	Advertisement limitations. Outdoor advertising shall be limited to the following: 
a.	Travel service facilities including lodgings, gas, food, camping.
b.	Areas of scenic beauty.
c.	Public attractions including historic, natural, scientific or recreational amenities.
d.	Other motorist services.
e.	Any combination of the facilities listed in subsection (9)a—d of this section. Further, the content of all advertising shall be directional in nature. 
(h)	On-premises signs. On-premises signs located within 100 feet of a regularly used part of the activity being advertised and located on the same property and for sale or for lease signs located on the property being advertised are not prohibited. 
(i)	Nonconforming signs. Any legally erected sign which would become nonconforming as a result of this article would be allowed to remain until purchased by the state department of transportation or the county, provided that the sign owner meets the requirements of state laws and rules and regulations governing such signs. 
(Code 1988, § 8-4-23)
Sec. 74-34. - Penalties. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction in the municipal court of the city, be punished as provided in section 1-7. 
(Code 1988, § 8-4-24)
Chapter 78 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Animal waste, § 10-59; buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; environment, ch. 34; utilities, ch. 98.
State Law reference— Authority to control solid waste, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(2).

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 78-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Collector means a person who, under agreements, verbal or written, with or without compensation, does the work of collecting and/or transporting solid waste from industries, offices, retail outlets, businesses, institutions, and/or similar locations, or from residential dwellings; provided, however, that this definition shall not include an individual collecting and/or transporting waste from his own single-family dwelling unit. 
Curbside junk means any items placed on a curb or sidewalk adjacent to a public street or on the public street with the obvious intent of disposing of such items. The term "curbside junk" shall include, but is not limited to, old tires, construction debris, any household belongings, supplies, furniture, clothing and appliances, except stoves and refrigerators. 
Disposal facility means any facility or location where any treatment, utilization, processing, or deposition of solid waste occurs. 
Disposal operation means the performance of solid waste disposal including administration, personnel, land, equipment, design and other elements necessary or used in the work of solid waste disposal. 
Disposal site means the location or land area where the final disposition of solid waste occurs. 
Garbage means putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
Hazardous waste means solid or liquid waste material resulting from the manufacture or use of pesticides and drugs (other than normal household use); pathological wastes; highly flammable or explosive wastes; toxic wastes; sewage sludges; and other waste material determined to be a likely hazard to the public health, safety, or environment, except radioactive waste materials as provided for in Rules of the Department of Natural Resources, Chapter 391-3-9-01 et seq., entitled "Radioactive Waste Material Disposal." 
Industrial waste means waste materials generated in industrial operations. 
Open dump means a disposal site at which solid waste from one or more sources is consolidated and left to decompose, burn or to otherwise create environmental pollution or nuisance. 
Putrescible wastes means wastes that are capable of being decomposed by microorganisms, including kitchen wastes, manure, offal, hatchery and poultry wastes, and garbage. 
Reclamation means a controlled method of sorting and storing solid wastes for future use in accordance with an approved plan. 
Refuse means all putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes (except body waste), including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned automobiles and solid commercial and industrial wastes. 
Rubbish means nonputrescible solid waste (excluding ashes), consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, wood, glass, bedding, crockery, and similar materials. 
Sanitary landfilling means a method of disposing of putrescible waste and/or hazardous waste on land by placing an earth cover thereon. 
Scavenge means uncontrolled picking from discarded waste materials. 
Solid waste means putrescible and nonputrescible wastes (except water carried body wastes), including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street refuse, dead animals, sewage sludges, animal manure, industrial wastes, residue from incineration, food processing wastes, construction wastes, hazardous wastes, and any other waste material in a solid or semisolid state not otherwise defined in this chapter. 
Solid waste handling means the storage, collection, transportation, treatment, utilization, processing, or disposing of solid wastes, or any combination thereof. 
Transfer station means a facility used to transfer solid wastes from one transportation vehicle to another for transportation to a disposal facility. 
(Code 1988, § 5-2-2)
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 78-2. - Purpose. 
The purpose of the rules and regulations contained in this chapter is to provide for the protection of the public health by prescribing the manner of storage, collection, transportation and disposal of residential and industrial waste, garbage and refuse. 
(Code 1988, § 5-2-1)
State Law reference— Authority to adopt regulations, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-30.9. 
Sec. 78-3. - Enforcement. 
(a)	Generally. The public works director shall be responsible for the administration and enforcement of this chapter. In the exercise of his solid waste management duties, the director shall: 
(1)	Supervise the collection of solid waste, including the operation and maintenance of equipment and the supervision of personnel; 
(2)	Establish collection schedules in accordance with the provisions of this chapter;
(3)	Supervise the operation and maintenance of the sanitary landfill and/or other disposal sites or facilities; and 
(4)	Inspect and regulate the operations of private collectors and private transportation and disposal systems to ensure that such operations are in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)	Limitations of authority. All regulatory actions of the public works director shall be subject to the review of the city manager. 
(c)	Appeal. Any person aggrieved by a requirement of, or a fee charged by, the public works director shall have the right to appeal to the city council, which may, upon hearing, confirm, modify or revoke such requirement or fee. 
(Code 1988, § 5-2-3)
Secs. 78-4—78-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL REGULATIONS 

Sec. 78-31. - Precollection practices. 
(a)	Generally. No person shall keep or store solid waste outside of any residence or building within the city, except in proper containers for collection or unless otherwise prepared, as set forth in this chapter or under the express prior approval of the public works director. Any unauthorized accumulation of solid waste is hereby declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited. The public works director shall notify the owner or occupant by written notice to remove the accumulation of solid waste from the property owned or occupied by him. Failure to remove such accumulation within two weeks of the date of such written notice shall be deemed a violation of this chapter and shall subject the violator to penalties set forth in this chapter. Each day during or upon which such unlawful accumulation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(b)	Containers. 
(1)	Garbage containers shall be provided by the owner or occupant of each residence or establishment sufficient in number to accommodate all waste generated by the resident or establishment between collections. Containers shall be of durable metal or plastic, watertight, nonabsorbent, rust-resistant, rodentproof, and easily cleanable. Containers shall be equipped with handles and tightly fitted covers and shall have a capacity of not less than 15 nor more than 40 gallons, except that bulk containers may be used of a type accepted by the public works director as suitable for mechanical collection by publicly owned equipment used for such collection. Containers which do not meet the standards of this section or which have defects causing waste to be scattered upon the ground during collection or which hamper or injure the persons collecting wastes shall be promptly replaced. 
(2)	Paper or plastic bags of a type, size and material designed for solid waste disposal may be used to contain refuse for storage and collection, provided they are unbroken, sealed and loaded in such manner that normal handling will not cause the bag to open. 
(c)	Rubbish. Rubbish may be stored for collection in paperboard boxes or other throwaway containers strong enough to retain the waste; loose paper or cuttings shall be tied in bundles. Rubbish containers or bundles shall not exceed 50 pounds in weight. Limbs or cuttings shall not exceed five inches in diameter nor five feet in length. 
(d)	Placement. On days designated as collection days for the respective routes, rubbish shall be placed for collection on the curb or beside the roadway in front of the residence or establishment owning such garbage or rubbish, but not in the gutter or in the street or alley in such manner as to interfere with pedestrian or vehicular traffic. Garbage shall be placed in a proper container at the rear of the dwelling or building. 
(e)	Scavenging. No person other than the owner or authorized collection personnel shall sift the contents of or remove anything from containers, boxes or bundles containing garbage or rubbish. 
(f)	Vehicles. The accumulation of one or more motor vehicles or any major part thereof which does not have a current state license plate or which is in one of the following conditions: 
(1)	Resting on blocks;
(2)	Without wheels;
(3)	With major parts missing;
(4)	Without tires; or
(5)	In a state of repair which precludes further use;
shall be an unauthorized accumulation of refuse, except where the vehicle is stored in an enclosed building or located on the premises of a licensed business enterprise operating in a lawful place and manner and the vehicle is necessary to the operation of such business. Where the motor vehicle or a major part thereof is not located in an enclosed building, such premises shall be screened on all sides by a fence or shrubbery so as to shield such accumulation from sight. 
(Code 1988, § 5-2-4)
Sec. 78-32. - Collection. 
(a)	Frequency. Garbage and rubbish shall be collected from residential premises at least weekly. Garbage and rubbish shall be collected from commercial and business establishments in congested areas daily except Sundays and legal holidays. 
(b)	Limitations. 
(1)	Industrial waste, large animals over 50 pounds, or waste from construction, demolition, landscaping or processing operations will not be collected, transported or disposed of by public equipment or facilities. Such waste collection, transportation, and disposal shall be by the owner and/or generators of such waste or animals, unless suitable arrangements are made with the city manager for proper disposal and fees. 
(2)	It shall be a violation of this chapter to place or cause to be placed in any container, box, or bundle, or otherwise for collection, any hazardous waste of any kind except upon specific prior arrangement with the public works director. 
(c)	Collection vehicles. Vehicles used for collection and transportation of solid waste shall be kept clean and in good repair. Vehicles used for collection and transportation of solid waste shall be constructed in such a manner that the contents thereof cannot be spilled, leaked or blown from the vehicle. Vehicles used for collection and transportation of solid waste shall be readily identifiable by letter, not less than three inches high and easily legible, painted on the door of the vehicle cab or in an equally conspicuous place, showing the owner's name, telephone number, state permit number, truck number, and rated load capacity in cubic yards.
