The chief of police, where good cause is shown, shall have the authority to consider any application under this article which is filed less than 48 hours before the date such parade is proposed to be conducted. 
(Code 1988, § 9-7-6)
Sec. 94-146. - Parade permit fee. 
There shall be paid at the time of filing the application for a parade permit such fee as fixed from time to time by the city council. 
(Code 1988, § 9-7-7)
Sec. 94-147. - Standards for issuance of parade permit. 
The chief of police shall issue a permit as provided for under this article when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds that: 
(1)	The conduct of the parade will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route; 
(2)	The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to the city; 
(3)	The conduct of such parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of ambulances as to prevent normal ambulance service to portions of the city other than that to be occupied by the proposed line of march and areas contiguous thereto; 
(4)	The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to such assembly areas; 
(5)	The conduct of such parade will not interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment en route to a fire; 
(6)	The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route; and 
(7)	The parade is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising any product, goods or event, and is not designed to be held purely for private profit. 
(Code 1988, § 9-7-8)
Sec. 94-148. - Notice of rejection of application for parade permit. 
The chief of police shall act upon the application for a parade permit within three days after the filing thereof. If the chief of police disapproves the application, he shall mail to the applicant, within five days after the date upon which the application was filed, a notice of his action, stating the reasons for his denial of the permit. 
(Code 1988, § 9-7-9)
Sec. 94-149. - Appeal procedure. 
Any person aggrieved shall have the right to appeal the denial of a parade permit to the city council. The appeal shall be taken within three days after notice. The city council shall act upon the appeal within 14 days after its receipt. 
(Code 1988, § 9-7-10)
Sec. 94-150. - Alternative permit. 
The chief of police in denying an application for a parade permit shall be empowered to authorize the conduct of the parade on a date, at a time, or over a route different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within five days after notice of the action of the chief of police, file a written notice of acceptance with the chief of police. An alternate parade permit shall conform to the requirements of, and shall have the effect of a parade permit under, this article. 
(Code 1988, § 9-7-11)
Sec. 94-151. - Notice to city and other officials. 
Immediately upon the issuance of a parade permit, the chief of police shall send a copy thereof to the following: 
(1)	The city manager;
(2)	The mayor;
(3)	The city attorney;
(4)	The fire chief.
(Code 1988, § 9-7-12)
Sec. 94-152. - Contents of parade permit. 
Each parade permit shall state the following information: 
(1)	Starting time;
(2)	Minimum speed;
(3)	Maximum speed;
(4)	Maximum interval of space to be maintained between the units of the parade;
(5)	The portions of the streets to be traversed that may be occupied by the parade;
(6)	The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions thereof;
(7)	Such other information as the chief of police shall find necessary to the enforcement of this article. 
(Code 1988, § 9-7-13)
Sec. 94-153. - Duties of permittee. 
A permittee under this article shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances. 
(Code 1988, § 9-7-14)
Sec. 94-154. - Possession of permit. 
The parade chair or other person heading or leading such activity shall carry the parade permit upon his person during the conduct of the parade. 
(Code 1988, § 9-7-15)
Sec. 94-155. - Public conduct during parades. 
(a)	Interference. No person shall unreasonably hamper, obstruct or impede, or interfere with any parade or parade assembly or with any person, vehicle or animal participating or used in a parade. 
(b)	Driving through parades. No driver of a vehicle, streetcar or trackless trolley shall drive between the vehicles or persons comprising a parade when such vehicles or persons are in motion and are conspicuously designated as a parade. 
(c)	Parking on parade route. The chief of police shall have the authority, when reasonably necessary, to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along a highway or part thereof constituting a part of the route of a parade. The chief of police shall post signs to such effect, and it shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation thereof. No person shall be liable for parking on a street unposted in violation of this article. 
(Code 1988, § 9-7-16)
Sec. 94-156. - Revocation of parade permit. 
The chief of police shall have the authority to revoke a parade permit issued under this article upon application of the standards for issuance as set forth in this article. 
(Code 1988, § 9-7-17)
Sec. 94-157. - Horses. 
Any person or group riding or otherwise directly in control of any horse, mule, donkey or other animal in a parade shall provide, at such person's own expense, a follower, who shall follow along behind such animal or group of animals and collect any excrement dropped by such animal before the next person or vehicle crosses over the point where such waste was dropped. 
(Ord. No. 13-01-07A, § 1, 1-7-2013)
Chapter 98 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; electrical, § 14-81 et seq.; businesses, ch. 18; environment, ch. 34; flood damage prevention, ch. 42; historical preservation, ch. 46; planning and development, ch. 70; solid waste, ch. 78; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82; subdivisions, ch. 86; electric supplier tax, § 90-231 et seq.
State Law reference— Grants for water and sewer service, O.C.G.A. § 36-40-20 et seq.; powers concerning water system, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-5.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 98-1. - Administrative responsibility. 
(a)	The municipal electrical distribution system shall be under the immediate supervision of the chief electrician, who shall perform all acts necessary for the prudent, efficient, and economical management and protection of the electrical system, subject to the approval and confirmation of the city manager. 
(b)	The municipal gas distribution system shall be under the immediate supervision of the gas superintendent, who shall perform all acts necessary for the prudent, efficient, and economical management and protection of the gas system, subject to the approval and confirmation of the city manager. 
(c)	The municipal water distribution and sewage systems shall be under the immediate supervision of the superintendent of water and wastewater, who shall perform all acts necessary for the prudent, efficient, and economical management and protection of the water and sewage systems, subject to the approval and confirmation of the city manager. 
(Code 1988, § 6-1-1)
Sec. 98-2. - Backflow prevention and cross connection control. 
The supervisor of the water distribution department of the city is authorized and directed to prepare and promulgate policies and procedures relating to control of the sewer system and the water system so as to enforce backflow prevention and cross connection controls applicable thereto. Such policies and procedures when developed and after approval and adoption by the mayor and council at a regular meeting shall be enforced and shall have the same effect as laws and ordinances of the city. A copy of the policies and procedures as adopted and as amended by the mayor and council shall be available for inspection. 
(Code 1988, § 6-4-1)
Sec. 98-3. - Franchise fees payable by city. 
Use by the City of Hogansville of the streets, alleys, public places and other property of the city for the operation of the city's water, sewer, electric and natural gas utilities is expressly conditioned upon payment of franchise fees as hereinafter set forth. Beginning in May 2013, and on a monthly basis thereafter, each utility enterprise of the city shall add to its bills, collect and pay to the general fund of the city the following percentage of the gross sales for the previous month of water, sewer, electric and natural gas services to all of the city's customers served within the corporate limits of the city, to wit: 

 
(Ord. No. 12-09-17A, § 1, 9-17-2012; Ord. No. 13-05-20, § 1, 5-20-2013)
Secs. 98-4—98-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER, SEWERS AND ELECTRICITY 

Sec. 98-31. - Use of public waters required. 
(a)	The owner of each house, building or property used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes situated in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now located, or may in the future be located, a public water line of the city, shall install at his expense suitable water facilities therein, and shall connect the facilities directly with the proper water line in accordance with the provisions of this section, within 90 days after the date of official notice to do so; provided that a public water line is within 200 feet of the owner's property line and access is available over public land or through a public utility easement. 
(b)	This section shall not apply to any such owner who already has suitable water facilities by use of a well on the date of adoption of the ordinance from which this section derives. 
(Code 1988, § 6-1-1.1)
Sec. 98-32. - Inspections. 
The city manager, or other designated employees, may enter the premises of any utility user at any reasonable time to examine the condition of the pipes, meters and fixtures. 
(Code 1988, § 6-1-2)
Sec. 98-33. - Application for utilities. 
Application for the use of utilities shall be made to the city clerk by the owner or agent of the property to be benefitted, designating the location of the property and stating the purpose for which utilities may be required. 
(Code 1988, § 6-1-3)
Sec. 98-34. - Connection charges. 
(a)	In addition to the $100.00 per tap fee per lot, the charges for installing, at the request of the customer, underground electric service shall be as follows: 
(1)	Primary cables, per foot .....$2.50 
Minimum charge .....375.00 
(2)	Secondary cables, per foot .....2.50 
Minimum charge .....225.00 
(b)	Except for the $100.00 per tap fee per lot, there shall be no charge to the customer for: 
(1)	Overhead electric service; or
(2)	Underground electric service which is determined to be in the best interest of the city. 
(c)	All cables between the city's metering equipment and the customer's switch gear shall be installed, owned and maintained by the customer. 
(d)	The city may charge a customer for relocating any overhead or underground electrical service when such relocation is at the request of, for the benefit of, or due to the fault of the customer. The charge for such relocation shall be equal to the labor, materials and overhead costs of the city. 
(e)	All fees shall be paid before the city's work is begun.
(Ord. of 8-15-2002, § 6-1-19)
Sec. 98-35. - Tapping and connection charges. 
(a)	Upon the application for a new tap and service connection by the consumer for water, the applicant shall pay to the city clerk such amount as established from time to time by the city council to cover the cost of the meter, fittings, pipe from the main to the property line, labor and fire protection costs. For larger meters, the customer will be charged for the cost of the meter, plus the cost of installation. 
(b)	Upon application for a new service tap and service connection by any consumer for gas, the applicant shall pay to the city clerk such sum as established from time to time by the city council for the first 25 feet of service line, plus the cost of the service line for each additional foot required to place service at the desired location. 
(1)	The customer or builder shall provide a location for the gas meter acceptable to the city. The city reserves the right to refuse to set a meter in an unacceptable position. Meters will not be located within less than six feet of heating appliances, near furnaces, nor inside or under houses, nor placed in any situation where they will be inaccessible or liable to injury. 
(2)	When, to accommodate different tenants, two or more meters are desired in a building, the city will set as many meters as there are separate customers, connecting the meters to one service pipe, provided the risers of pipes leading to these different tenants are terminated according to city specifications. 
(c)	Upon application for new electrical service, the applicant shall pay to the city clerk such sum as established from time to time by the city council for the first 50 feet of service line and first utility pole and the city's cost for wire thereafter to place service at the desired location. 
(d)	Upon application for connection to the city's sanitary sewerage lines, the applicant shall pay to the city clerk such sum as established from time to time by the city council. 
(e)	When any tap requires the cutting of pavement, sidewalks, curbing or the boring of the road, the customer is required to pay this cost in addition to the cost in subsection (d) of this section. 
(f)	The city shall own and maintain the gas line from the main to the meter and the property owner shall own and maintain the service line from the meter. 
(g)	The city shall own and maintain the electric line from the pole to the masthead for the service wire to enter the building and the property owner shall own and maintain the line therefrom. 
(h)	All work upon the service line shall be performed by a licensed plumber, electrician, or owner, as may be applicable. 
(Code 1988, § 6-1-4)
Sec. 98-36. - Meters. 
Each building or structure using city utilities shall have a meter installed by the city. All such meters are the property of the city. The city reserves the sole right to turn on, turn off, disconnect, move, or reset all meters. 
(Code 1988, § 6-1-5)
Sec. 98-37. - Service line regulations. 
Each gas and/or water service line shall contain a stopcock and waste cock where the gas and/or water may be turned off on the owner's premises. Only pipe approved for potable water shall be used for any water service line. 
(Code 1988, § 6-1-6)
Sec. 98-38. - Waste prohibition. 
(a)	Consumers shall prevent unnecessary waste of water and keep all water outlets closed when not in actual use. Hydrants, urinals, water closets, bathtubs and other fixtures must not be left running for any purpose other than the use for which they were intended. When any such waste occurs, the water service may be terminated. 
(b)	Consumers should be energy conservation conscious. Temperatures of the interiors of buildings and that of hot water should be maintained at comfortable, but not at unnecessarily high or low (according to the season) settings. Furnaces should be cleaned and properly adjusted. Efforts should be made to make buildings energy efficient. When any such waste occurs on a continuing basis, utility service may be discontinued until corrections are made. 
(Code 1988, § 6-1-7)
Sec. 98-39. - Sprinkling restrictions. 
In case of water shortage or scarcity, the city council may by resolution place any restrictions upon the use of water for irrigation or sprinkling purposes which it deems necessary. 
(Code 1988, § 6-1-8)
Sec. 98-40. - Use during fire alarms. 
During all fire alarms, the use of hoses and other apparatus maintaining a constant flow of water by persons other than municipal firefighters is absolutely forbidden. 
(Code 1988, § 6-1-9)
Sec. 98-41. - Interruptions in service. 
(a)	The uninterrupted service of any utility provided by the city is not guaranteed to any party purchasing or receiving those services from the city. No liability will be assumed by the city for damage to equipment or property or injuries to persons due to interruptions in any utility services. 
(b)	The term "interruptions" as employed in this section shall be defined as the occurrence of some act during the period of use or prescription which is sufficient to cause a deviation from the norm, regardless of the cause of that act. 
(Code 1988, § 6-1-10)
Sec. 98-42. - Utility rates. 
(a)	Electric. Electric rates shall be as established from time to time by the mayor and council, with the exception of the environmental compliance cost recovery factor (ECCR) and the annual adjustment for total cost of power. The monthly environmental compliance cost recovery adjustment in cents per kWh shall be added to all electric meters for service. The ECCR shall represent an amount no higher than that which may be calculated using the environmental compliance cost recovery reporting issued annually by the City of Hogansville's electric supplier MEAG Power. 
Beginning with bills calculated after September 1, 2012, the electric rate charges per unit (kWh) shall be modified on an annual basis to reflect the increase or decrease in total cost of power purchased by the City of Hogansville from the Municipal Electric Authority of Georgia (MEAG). Variances of such wholesale total power supply costs, either in excess or shortfall, shall be included within the rate calculation for each of the city's customers on equal per kWh basis. 
(1)	Residential service. The residential service schedule is applicable to all residential customers for domestic use in individual residences or apartments where the largest motor does not exceed 7½ horsepower. This service is only applicable to that required to operate residential lighting, cooking, heating, refrigeration and incidental power when applied to one meter to each residence or apartment unit. Power normally supplied under this rate will be normal 120-240 volts, single phase. 
(2)	Outdoor lighting service, city owned system. Outdoor lighting service is available in all areas served by the city electric system. Where poles other than wood are desired by a customer, he shall install, own and maintain such poles and the city shall install, own and maintain the brackets and lighting equipment. Where the use of underground conductors is desired by the customer, he shall install, own and maintain the underground conductors and the risers up the poles. Security lighting service will be provided only at locations which are accessible to the city trucks for servicing purposes. 
a.	The customer shall pay, in advance of installation, the actual cost of materials necessary for installation, to include necessary poles, wire, and luminaire. 
b.	When the customer pays for the total cost of 175 watt luminaire, pole, labor, etc., the city shall make a charge as fixed from time to time by the city council for energy and maintenance. 
c.	The term "maintain," as it applies to security lights, means the replacement of lamps and glassware as required at regular intervals or as soon as can reasonably be done after notification is received by the city that service has been interrupted. However, the customer shall reimburse the city for the cost of any such maintenance work which is required because of vandalism. 
(3)	Industrial service. 
a.	Generally. Industrial service is applicable to industrial customers whose main function is the manufacture of finished products, the extraction, fabrication or processing of raw materials, the preservation of raw materials or finished products, for all legitimate power and residential lighting requirements in the operation of the industrial plants. No electricity may be resold, transmitted to other premises, nor used in related commercial enterprise without the express consent of the city. Motor starting current must conform to city requirements. 
b.	Determination of demand. The demand shall be based on the highest 30-minute kW measurements during the current month and the preceding 11 months and not less than 100 percent of the highest demand occurring during any previous summer month (June through October). In no case shall the demand be less than 50 kW. 
c.	Purchased power adjustment rider. Purchased power adjustment rider will be added to established rates. 
d.	Taxes. The established rates do not include tax. 
(b)	Fuel charges and sales tax. Fuel charges and state sales tax shall be added to all rates where applicable. 
(c)	Gas. Rates for consumers of natural gas of and from the natural gas distribution system of the city shall be established from time to time by the city council. 
(1)	The industrial schedule is available to any commercial, institutional or industrial user for any purpose exclusive of resale and for service at one location through one metering point and where the customer maintains adequate standby fuel and equipment. The availability of service at this schedule is dependent upon the city having gas delivery capacity in excess of the then existing requirements of other customers and having available from its supplier at the delivery point nearest to the customer an adequate supply of natural gas to meet the customer's requirements. 
(2)	State sales tax is added when applicable.
(3)	Unauthorized use of gas. If, upon one-hour notice by the city, the customer fails to comply with a curtailment notice calling for complete or partial curtailment of gas deliveries and by reason thereof the city is charged by its supplier with overrun penalties, the customer shall be billed for the amount of such penalties which are due to its failure to comply with such curtailment notices. 
(4)	The payment of an overrun penalty shall not, under any circumstances, be considered as giving the customer the right to take unauthorized overrun gas, nor shall payment be considered to exclude or limit any other remedies (including turning off the gas service valve at the customer's premises) available to the city or other customer against the offending customer for failing to comply with its obligation to operate within the provisions of all curtailment orders. 
(5)	The availability of service at the rate schedule shall be at the city's option and is dependent upon the city having gas delivery capacity in excess of the requirements of all other customers during the period of curtailment. 
(6)	Deliveries under the industrial schedule shall be subject to curtailment or complete interruption wherever in the discretion of the city such curtailment or complete interruption of service is necessary in order to assure continuous service to customers served on a firm basis and equitable allocation of gas among all customers of the city. 
(7)	The rates fixed in this subsection are based upon rates presently authorized by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC). In the event the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission shall hereafter authorize an increase or decrease in the cost of such gas to the city, the city clerk shall adjust the rates contained in this subsection to reflect the same ratio of cost to selling price as are contained in this subsection, i.e., basic cubic foot selling price to residential customers is the cost to the city multiplied by 1.1. The city clerk shall notify the council of any raises or pending raises as soon as it becomes known to the city clerk. 
(d)	Sanitary sewage. Customers shall be billed for sewage services in accordance with a schedule as established from time to time by the city council. 
(e)	Water. 
(1)	Generally. Municipal water rates for customers shall be as established from time to time by the city council. 
(2)	Fire protection service rates. Fire protection service water rates are applicable to all customers having water facilities which are designed and used exclusively for the purpose of fire protection and suppression. The charge is for availability of water for fire protection and suppression purposes and is based upon the facilities available for such purposes, and shall be as established from time to time by the city council. The annual fire protection service charge shall be prorated and billed on the city monthly utility bill and shall be due and payable by the tenth of each month. 
(Code 1988, § 6-1-11; Ord. No. 12-09-17B, § 1, 9-17-2012; Ord. No. 12-09-17C, § 1, 9-17-2012) 
Sec. 98-43. - Reading meters; utility bills. 
Meters shall be read on the same day of each month, as nearly as possible, and bills shall be mailed within ten working days thereafter. All bills shall be due and payable within 15 days of the date of the bill. Bills not so paid shall have a penalty of ten percent added thereto. 
(Code 1988, § 6-1-12)
Sec. 98-44. - Collection policy; discontinuance of service for failure to pay utilities. 
It is the policy of the city to administer a fair and equitable program of collection procedures which will curtail habitually late payments, but yet will not penalize those persons or customers who are occasionally tardy with their payment. The following conditions shall apply as to the collection policy for the city: 
(1)	The city shall cause to be delivered, each customer's utility bill, on or before the 25th day of each calendar month. 
(2)	If on the tenth of the month, the customer has not fully paid the amount shown on the invoice or bill which was mailed on the 25th of the preceding month, he shall be mailed a late notice indicating such delinquency on the 11th of that month. 
(3)	If the customer has not fully paid the previous month's utility bill, as indicated by that invoice received or mailed on the 25th of the previous month, his utilities and city services shall be disconnected on the 26th of the following calendar month. 
(4)	A customer's service shall be disconnected upon the receipt of a returned check.
(5)	The city shall make notification by mail whenever this policy requires that notice be given. 
(Ord. of 4-20-1998, § 6-1-13)
Sec. 98-45. - Charges for turning utility service on. 
If the utility service to any premises is turned off for any reason, a reconnection charge as established by city council shall be made for turning the utilities back on. Service shall not be restored to any person or household until all delinquencies shall have been paid in full. 
(Code 1988, § 6-1-14)
Sec. 98-46. - Deposit required. 
(a)	Each person desiring to become a customer of the city for water, gas or electrical utility service shall make application for such service, either in person, or by their duly authorized agent upon forms provided by the city for such purpose. Any such application for service will not be accepted by the city unless the conditions and provisions of the ordinances, rules and regulations of the city are complied with. 
(b)	At the time of application for utility service, the customer will pay to the city a utility deposit in an amount as established by the city council, which shall be retained by the city, without interest, for so long as it is deemed necessary and service is given to the customer by the city. 
(1)	Commercial service. Commercial service shall be billed at 2½ times the anticipated monthly bill based upon past history, if any, or upon the anticipated use. The customer may furnish the city a surety bond in lieu of the cash deposit. 
(2)	Industrial service: Industrial service shall be billed the same as commercial service, or as may be determined by contract approved by the city council and executed prior to delivery of service. 
(c)	Upon application therefor, and after consideration of appropriate credit investigation, past history of service, if any, and such other facts as may be appropriate, the city clerk may waive the deposit requirements or may require a deposit of a lesser amount. 
(d)	Any utility deposit may be applied by the city to payment of past due bills and the customer in making a subsequent application for service may be required to make another utility deposit. 
(e)	Any customer whose service is terminated for nonpayment may be required to make an additional deposit up to the amount of double the anticipated monthly bill based on past history, if any, or upon anticipated use. 
(Code 1988, § 6-1-15)
Sec. 98-47. - Alteration of or damage to metering equipment; theft of services. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person intentionally and without authority to injure or destroy any meter, pipe, conduit, wire, line, post, lamp or other apparatus belonging to the city, or intentionally and without authority to prevent a meter from properly registering the quantity of such service supplied, or in any way to interfere with the proper action of the city, or to intentionally divert any services of the city or otherwise intentionally and without authority to use or cause to be used any service manufactured, sold or distributed by the city. 
(b)	Where there is no evidence to the contrary, the person performing any of the illegal acts set forth in subsection (a) of this section and/or the person who with knowledge of such violation receives the benefit of such service without proper charge as a result of such improper action shall be presumed to be responsible for such acts of tampering or diversion. 
(c)	Violators of the provisions of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-7 of this Code. 
(Code 1988, § 6-1-16)
State Law reference— Theft of service, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25. 
Sec. 98-48. - Meter testing. 
Any utility user who believes his meter measures inaccurately who desires to have the meter tested for accuracy shall pay a deposit as fixed from time to time by the city council to the city clerk. The city shall have the meter tested by an independent firm which shall furnish a written report, by serial number, a copy of which will be furnished the user. If the meter is found to be within the limits acceptable to the public service commission, the user shall forfeit his deposit and no adjustment shall be made. If the meter tested is outside those limits, the deposit shall be returned and an appropriate adjustment shall be made to the user's account. 
(Code 1988, § 6-1-17)
Sec. 98-49. - Discounts. 
(a)	Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following words, terms and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Head of household means any person living with one or more persons in the household who are related to him by blood or marriage and whose income is the primary means of support for such household. 
Income means money received from any source whether the result of employment, return on investments or savings, or whether the money shall be from welfare payments, social security benefits, aid to dependent children benefits or other payments or benefits from federal, state, city or county governments, or any of the agencies or departments of such governments. 
Primary individual means any person living alone or living with one or more persons who are not related to him by blood or marriage and whose income is the primary means of support for such household. 
(b)	Utilities discount for certain individuals created. There is hereby created a utilities discount in an amount as fixed from time to time by the city council for the head of a family or the primary individual of a household who is 65 years of age or older and who otherwise meets the qualifications contained in this section. 
(c)	Application or utilities discount; requirements. The head of household or primary individual of a household desiring to obtain such utility discount shall make an annual application therefor. Such application shall be approved by the city council if the following requirements are met: 
(1)	The person making application for such utility discount is the head of household or primary individual of a household, and is 65 years of age or older. 
(2)	The current total income from all sources for all persons living in the same household does not exceed such annual sum as established and adjusted from time to time by the council using US Department of Agriculture (USDA) figures; provided, however, that any property owner who is head of household or the primary individual of a household and who is entitled to the low income double homestead exemption under the law of the state shall be deemed to meet the total income provisions of this subsection. 
(3)	The person making such application for a utility discount must have been a user of city utilities for at least a period of six months. 
(d)	Application for discount to be made under oath; filing; misrepresentation of facts in application. 
(1)	The application for utilities discount shall be made under oath and filed with the city clerk and shall be effective upon approval by the city council. 
(2)	It shall be unlawful for any person to misrepresent facts in any application made for the purpose of securing such discount. Any person violating this subsection shall be punished as provided in section 1-7 of this Code. Any discounts given or received by virtue of a false application may be terminated immediately. 
(Code 1988, § 6-1-18)
Sec. 98-50. - After hours disconnect fee. 
There will be a charge of $35.00 per visit for disconnecting any utility customer which occurs: 
(1)	After 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, or at any time on Saturday, Sunday or any holiday; and 
(2)	When such disconnection is required due to problems with the customer's utility service which requires correction or repair by the customer. 
(Ord. of 9-18-1995, § 6-1-19)
Sec. 98-51. - Restriction on outdoor watering of landscapes; penalties. 
(a)	Outdoor watering for purposes of planting, growing, managing, or maintaining ground cover, trees, shrubs, or other plants in the corporate limits of the city may occur only between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m.; provided, however, that this limitation shall not create any limitation upon the following outdoor water uses: 
(1)	Commercial raising, harvesting, or storing of crops; feeding, breeding, or managing livestock or poultry; the commercial production or storing of feed for use in the production of livestock, including, but not limited to, cattle, calves, swine, hogs, goats, sheep, and rabbits, or for use in the production of poultry, including, but not limited to, chickens, hens, ratites, and turkeys; producing plants, trees, fowl, or animals; or the commercial production of aquacultural, horticultural, dairy, livestock, poultry, eggs, and apiarian products or as otherwise defined in O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3; 
(2)	Capture and reuse of cooling system condensate or stormwater in compliance with applicable ordinances and state guidelines; 
(3)	Reuse of gray water in compliance with O.C.G.A. § 31-3-5.2 and applicable local board of health regulations; 
(4)	Use of reclaimed wastewater by a designated user from a system permitted by the Environmental Protection Division of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources to provide reclaimed wastewater; 
(5)	Watering personal food gardens;
(6)	Watering new and replanted plant, seed, or turf in landscapes, golf courses, or sports turf fields during installation and for a period of 30 days immediately following the date of installation; 
(7)	Drip irrigation or irrigation using soaker hoses;
(8)	Hand watering with a hose with automatic cutoff or handheld container;
(9)	Use of water withdrawn from private water wells or surface water by an owner or operator of property if such well or surface water is on said property; 
(10)	Watering horticultural crops held for sale, resale, or installation;
(11)	Watering athletic fields, golf courses, or public turf grass recreational areas;
(12)	Installation, maintenance, or calibration of irrigation systems; or
(13)	Hydroseeding.
(b)	It shall be unlawful for any water customer of the city to use or allow the use of water in violation of the restrictions on outdoor water use contained within this ordinance. Any persons who shall violate the provisions of this section shall upon conviction be punished as provided in section 1-7 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 10-12-20-A, § 1, 12-20-2010)
Secs. 98-52—98-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - UNDERGROUND UTILITY DAMAGE PREVENTION 

Sec. 98-81. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Damage means the substantial weakening of structural or lateral support of an underground utility, penetration or destruction of any protective coating, housing or other protective device of an underground utility, and the partial or complete severance of an underground utility. 
Demolish and demolition mean any operation by which a structure or mass of material is wrecked, razed, moved or removed by means of any tools or discharge of explosives. 
Excavate and excavation mean an operation for the purpose of the movement or removal of earth, rock or other materials in or on the ground by use of mechanized equipment or by discharge of explosives, and including augering, backfilling, digging; ditching, drilling, grading, plowing-in, pulling-in, ripping, scraping, trenching and tunneling, but not including the tilling of soil for agricultural purposes. 
Mechanized equipment means equipment operated by means of mechanical power including trenchers, bulldozers, power shovels, augers, backhoes, scrapers, drills, cable and pipe plows and other equipment used for plowing-in or pulling-in cable or pipe. 
Operator means the city or any utility commission who owns or operates a utility within the city. 
Person means any individual, any corporation, partnership, association, or any other entity organized under the laws of any state, any subdivision or instrumentality of a state and any employee, agent or legal representative thereof. 
Utility means any line system or facility used for producing, storing, conveying, transmitting, or distributing communication, electricity, gas, petroleum, petroleum products, hazardous liquids, water, steam or sewerage. 
Working day means every day, except Saturday, Sunday, and national and legal state holidays. 
(Code 1988, § 6-2-2)
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 98-82. - Excavation and demolition permits; effect. 
A permit issued pursuant to a law authorizing excavation or demolition operations shall not be deemed to relieve a person from the responsibility for complying with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1988, § 6-2-3)
Sec. 98-83. - Prohibition. 
Except as provided in section 98-86, no person may excavate in a street, highway, public space, a private easement of an operator, or near the location of a utility installed on the premises of a customer served by such utility, or demolish a building without having first ascertained in the manner prescribed in sections 98-84 and 98-85 the location of all underground utilities in the area that would be affected by the proposed excavation or demolition. Each operator shall maintain a list of all underground utilities and plans or maps showing their location. 
(Code 1988, § 6-2-4)
Sec. 98-84. - Notice of intent to excavate or demolish. 
(a)	Except as provided in section 98-86, before commencing any excavation or demolition operation designated in section 98-83, each person responsible for such excavation or demolition shall serve written or telephonic notice of intent to excavate or demolish at least three, but not more than ten full working days on each operator. In the case of the city, such notice should be given to the city manager or city clerk. 
(b)	The written or telephonic notice required by subsection (a) of this section must contain the name, address and telephone number of the person filing the notice of intent, and, if different, the person responsible for the excavation or demolition, the starting date, anticipated duration, and type of excavation or demolition to be conducted, the location of the proposed excavation or demolition and whether or not explosives are to be used. 
(c)	If the notification required by this section is made by telephone, an adequate record of such notification shall be maintained by the operators to document compliance with the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1988, § 6-2-5)
Sec. 98-85. - Response to notice of intent to excavate or demolish. 
(a)	Each operator or designated representative notified in accordance with section 98-84 shall, not less than two working days in advance of the proposed excavation or demolition (unless a shorter period is provided by agreement between the person responsible for the excavation or demolition and the operator or designated representative), supply, by use of maps when appropriate, the following information to the person responsible for the excavation or demolition: 
(1)	The approximate location and description of all of its underground utilities which may be damaged as a result of the excavation or demolition; 
(2)	The location and description of all utility markers indicating the approximate location of the underground utilities; and 
(3)	Any other information that would assist that person in locating and thereby avoiding damage to the underground utilities, including providing adequate temporary markings indicating the approximate location of the underground utility in locations where permanent utility markers do not exist. 
(b)	For purposes of this section, the approximate location of underground utilities is defined as a strip of land at least three feet wide but not wider than the width of the utility plus 1½ feet on either side of the utility. 
(c)	Where demolition of a building is proposed, operators shall be given reasonable time to remove or protect their utilities before demolition of the building is commenced. 
(Code 1988, § 6-2-6)
Sec. 98-86. - Emergency excavation or demolition. 
Compliance with the notice requirements of section 98-84 is not required of persons responsible for emergency excavation or demolition to ameliorate an imminent danger to life, health, or property; provided, however, that such persons give, as soon as practicable, oral notice of the emergency excavation or demolition to each operator having underground utilities located in the area where such excavation or demolition is to be performed and requests emergency assistance from each operator so identified in locating and providing immediate protection to its underground utilities. An imminent danger to life, health or property exists whenever there is a substantial likelihood that loss of life, health or property will result before the procedures under sections 98-84 and 98-85 can be fully complied with. 
(Code 1988, § 6-2-7)
Sec. 98-87. - Precautions to avoid damage. 
In addition to the notification requirements of section 98-84, each person responsible for any excavation or demolition operation designated in section 98-83 shall: 
(1)	Plan the excavation or demolition to avoid damage to or minimize interference with underground utilities in and near the construction area; 
(2)	Maintain a clearance between an underground utility and the cutting edge or point of any mechanized equipment, taking into account the known limit of control of such cutting edge or point, as may be reasonably necessary to avoid damage to such utility; and 
(3)	Provide such support for underground utilities in and near the construction area, including during backfill operations, as may be reasonably necessary for the protection of such utilities. 
(Code 1988, § 6-2-8)
Sec. 98-88. - Excavation or demolition damage. 
(a)	Except as provided by subsection (b) of this section, each person responsible for any excavation or demolition operation designated in section 98-83 that results in any damage to an underground utility shall, immediately upon discovery of such damage, notify the operator of such utility of the location and nature of the damage and shall allow the operator reasonable time to accomplish necessary repairs before completing the excavation or demolition in the immediate area of such utility. 
(b)	Each person responsible for any excavation or demolition operation designated in section 98-83 that results in damage to an underground utility permitting the escape of any flammable, toxic or corrosive gas or liquid shall, immediately upon discovery of such damage, notify the operator, police and fire departments, and take any other action as may be reasonably necessary to protect persons and property and to minimize the hazards until arrival of the operator's personnel or police and fire departments. 
(Code 1988, § 6-2-9)
Sec. 98-89. - Penalties. 
Any person who violates any provision of this article shall upon conviction be punished as provided in section 1-7. This article does not affect any civil remedies for personal injury or property (including underground utilities) damage except as otherwise specifically provided for in this article. 
(Code 1988, § 6-2-10)
Secs. 98-90—98-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SEWER USE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 98-111. - Definitions and abbreviations. 
(a)	The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Act and the act mean the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act, as amended, 33 USC 1251 et seq., as it may be amended. 
Authorized representative of industrial user means any one of the following: 
(1)	A principal executive officer at least the level of vice-president, if the industrial user is a corporation; 
(2)	A general partner or proprietor if the industrial user is a partnership or proprietorship, respectively; 
(3)	A person designated by an authorized representative as defined in subsections (1) or (2) of this definition where such designated person is responsible for the overall operation of the facilities from which the discharge originates. 
Biochemical oxygen demand means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure, five days at 20 degrees Celsius expressed in milligrams per liter, mg/l. 
Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five feet outside the inner face of the building wall. 
Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal, also called house connection. 
Categorical standards means national pretreatment standards or any regulation applicable to industrial users and containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency in accordance with Section 307(b) and (c) of the Act. 
Chemical oxygen demand means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the oxidation of organic and oxidizable inorganic material, measured by using a strong chemical oxidizing agent in an acidic medium, expressed in milligrams per liter, mg/l. 
Combined sewer means a sewer intended to receive both wastewater and stormwater or surface water. 
Composite sample means the accumulation of a number of individual samples over a period of time, so taken as to represent the nature of the wastewater. 
Cooling water means the water discharged from any use such as air conditioning, cooling refrigeration, or to which the only pollutant added is heat. 
Designated city representative means the city manager or his duly authorized agent. 
Domestic wastewater means wastewater derived principally from dwellings, business buildings and institutions, exclusive of industrial wastewater. 
Easement means an acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others. 
Environmental Protection Agency and EPA mean the regional administrator or other duly authorized official of such federal agency. 
Environmental Protection Division and EPD mean the state department of natural resources, environmental protection division or any authorized official of such state agency. 
Floatable oil means oil, fat or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. A wastewater shall be considered free of floatable fat if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection system. 
Garbage means the animal and vegetable waste resulting from the domestic or commercial handling, preparation, cooking and serving of foods. 
General pretreatment regulations means "The General Pretreatment Regulations for Existing and New Sources of Pollution," published in the Federal Register, 40 CFR 403, on June 26, 1978, and any revisions to such document. 
Grab sample means a sample which is taken from a wastewater stream on a one-time basis with no regard to the flow in the wastewater stream and without consideration of time. 
Grease means a material composed primarily of fats, oil, and grease from animal or vegetable sources. The terms "fats, oil, and grease" shall be deemed as grease by definition. Grease may also include petroleum-based products. 
Grease trap means a tank or vessel designed to remove floatable oil from the wastewater stream prior to discharge to the municipal system. 
Grit means the heavy suspended mineral matter present in water or wastewater such as sand, gravel or cinders. 
Grit trap means a tank or vessel designed to interrupt the flow of wastewater so as to cause sand, grit and similar heavy particles to be removed from the wastewater stream prior to discharge to the municipal system. 
Industrial wastes means the wastewater from industrial processes, trade or business as distinct from domestic or sanitary wastes. 
Interference means inhibition or disruption of the water pollution control facilities, city wastewater treatment processes or operations, or sludge processes, use, or disposal; which is a cause of or significantly contributes to either a violation of any requirement of the city's NPDES permit, including an increase in the magnitude or duration of a violation, or to the prevention of sludge use or disposal by the city in accordance with the following federal statutory provisions and regulations or permits issued thereunder (or more stringent state or city regulations): Section 405 of the Act, (33 USC 1345), the Solid Waste Disposal Act (SWDA), the Clean Air Act, and the Toxic Substances Control Act. An industrial user significantly contributes to such a permit violation or prevention of sludge use or disposal in accordance with authorities cited in this definition whenever such user: 
(1)	Discharges a daily pollutant loading in excess of that permitted by the provisions of this article or by federal or state law. 
(2)	Discharges wastewater which substantially differs in nature or constituents from the user's average discharge; or 
(3)	Knows or has reason to know that the user's discharge, alone or in conjunction with discharges from other sources, would result in an NPDES permit violation by the city or prevent sludge use or disposal in accordance with the authorities cited in this definition as they apply to the city's selected method of sludge management. 
Mass emission rate means the weight of material discharged during a given time interval. Unless otherwise specified, the mass emission rate shall mean pounds per year of the particular constituent or combination of constituents. 
May is permissive; shall is mandatory. 
Metered water means the amount of all sources of water, including wells, consumed by the sewer customer. 
National categorical pretreatment standard means any national pretreatment standard specifying properties which may be discharged to a water pollution control facility by existing or new industrial users in specific industrial subcategories. 
National pollutant discharge elimination system permit means a permit issued pursuant to Section 402 of the Act (33 USC 1342). 
National pretreatment standard and pretreatment standard mean any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by the EPA in accordance with Section 307(b) and (c) of the Act, which applies to industrial users. 
New source and new industrial user mean any new discharge, the construction of which is commenced after the publication of proposed categorical pretreatment standards (under Section 307 (b) of the Act) for such discharges. 
Person means any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, governmental entity, or any other legal entity, or the legal representatives, agents or assigns of such entity or individual. 
pH means the reciprocal of the logarithm of the hydrogen ion concentration. The concentration is the weight of hydrogen ions, in grams, per liter of solution. Neutral water, for example, has a pH value of seven and a hydrogen-ion concentration of 107. 
Pretreatment means the reduction of the amount of pollutants, the elimination of pollutants, or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties in wastewater to a less harmful state prior to or in lieu of discharging such pollutants into water pollution control facilities. 
Properly shredded garbage means the wastes from preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch in any dimension. 
Publicly owned pretreatment works and POTW mean a treatment works as defined by Section 212 of the Act, (33 USC 1292) which is owned in this instance by the city. This definition includes any sewers that convey wastewater to such a treatment works, but does not include pipes, sewers or other conveyances not connected to a facility providing treatment. 
Sanitary sewer means a sewer that carries liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions together with minor quantities of groundwater, stormwater and surface waters that are not admitted intentionally. 
Sewage means the spent water of a community. The preferred term is "wastewater." 
Sewer means a pipe or conduit that carries wastewater or drainage water. 
Significant industrial user means any industrial user of the city's wastewater disposal system who (i) has a discharge flow of 25,000 gallons or more per average work day; or (ii) has a flow greater than five percent of the flow in the city's wastewater treatment system; or (iii) has in his wastes toxic pollutants as defined pursuant to Section 307 of the Act or defined in the laws of the state; or (iv) is found by the city, state control agency or the Environmental Protection Agency to have significant impact, either singly or in combination with other contributing industries, on the wastewater treatment system, the quality of sludge, the system's effluent quality, or air emissions generated by the system. 
Sludge means the accumulated solids separated from liquids during wastewater processing. 
Slug means any discharge of water or wastewater which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than 15 minutes more than five times the average 24-hour concentration of flows during normal operation and shall adversely affect wastewater treatment works. 
Standard industrial classification means a classification pursuant to the Standard Industrial Classification Manual issued by the Executive Office of the President, Office of Management and Budget. 
Storm drain and storm sewer mean a sewer which carries stormwater and surface waters and drainage, but excludes sewage and industrial wastes, other than unpolluted cooling waters. 
Suspended solids means total suspended matter that either floats on the surface of, or is in suspension in, water, wastewater, or other liquids, and that is removable by laboratory filtering as prescribed in Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater. 
Toxic pollutant means any pollutant or combination of pollutants listed as toxic in regulations promulgated by the administrator of the EPA under the provision of the Clean Water Act, Section 307(a) or other acts. 
Unpolluted water means water of quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect, or water that would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards and would not be benefitted by discharge to the sanitary sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided. 
User means any person who contributes, causes or permits the contribution of wastewater into the city's water pollution control facilities. 
Waste means sewage and any and all other waste substances, liquid, solid, gaseous or radioactive, associated with human habitation, or of human or animal origin, or from any producing, manufacturing or processing operation of whatever nature, including such waste placed within containers of whatever nature prior to, and for purposes of, disposal. 
Wastewater means a combination of the water carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions, and commercial establishments, together with those groundwaters, surface waters and stormwaters as may be present. 
Wastewater facilities means the structures, equipment and processes required to collect, carry away and treat domestic and industrial wastes and dispose of the effluent. 
Wastewater treatment works means an arrangement of devices and structures for treating wastewater, industrial wastes and sludge. The term "wastewater treatment works" is sometimes used as synonymous with waste treatment plant or water pollution control plant. 
(b)	The following abbreviations shall have the following meanings:

 
(Code 1988, § 6-3-2; Ord. No. 09-12-07-A, § 2, 12-7-2009)
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 98-112. - Purpose. 
In order to provide for the public health and welfare, the city finds it is necessary to set uniform requirements for all users of the water pollution control facilities of the city; to establish effluent limits; to require pretreatment, where necessary, by system users; to regulate the use of municipal pollution control facilities through the issuance of permits to certain industrial users; to establish charges and fees for the equitable distribution of costs; and to enable the city to comply with all applicable state and federal laws. The purposes of this article are to prevent the introduction into the municipal pollution control facilities of pollutants which will interfere with the operation of the system or contaminate the resulting sludge; to prevent the introduction into municipal pollution facilities of pollutants which would pass through the facilities, inadequately treated, into receiving waters or the atmosphere, or otherwise be incompatible with the facilities; to improve the opportunity to recycle and reclaim wastewaters and sludges from the facilities; and to provide for equitable distribution of the cost of the municipal pollution control facilities. 
(Code 1988, § 6-3-1)
Secs. 98-113—98-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REGULATION OF USE 

Sec. 98-131. - Use of public sewers required. 
(a)	The owner of each house, building or property used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes situated in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now located, or may in the future be located, a public sanitary sewer of the city, shall install at his expense suitable toilet facilities therein, and shall connect the facilities directly with the proper sewer in accordance with the provisions of this article, within 90 days after the date of official notice to do so; provided that a public sewer is within 200 feet of the owner's property line and access is available over public land or through a public utility easement. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the city in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any human or animal excrement, garbage or objectionable waste. 
(c)	It shall be unlawful to discharge to any storm drain or natural outlet within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any wastewater or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this article. 
(Code 1988, § 6-3-3)
Sec. 98-132. - Private wastewater disposal. 
(a)	Private wastewater facilities, including privies, cesspools and septic tanks, are prohibited in all areas where public sewers are available as defined in subsection 98-131(a). 
(b)	Where a public sanitary sewer is not available, the building sewer shall be connected to a private wastewater disposal system complying with the provisions of this section. 
(c)	The type, capacities, location and layout of all private wastewater disposal systems shall comply with all recommendations of the state department of natural resources. Before commencement of construction on any private wastewater disposal system, except for septic tanks, the owner shall first obtain a written permit from the designated city representative. Septic tank installations are under the jurisdiction of the county health officer. All septic tanks constructed in the city shall be approved by the inspector of the health department of the county before the tank is placed in service. All building permits issued by the city, where a septic tank is required, shall be issued subject to the approval of the septic tank by the health official or inspector of the health department of the county. 
(d)	It shall be unlawful to discharge septic tank effluent or cesspool overflow to any open drain, ditch, stream, or well penetrating water-bearing formations. 
(e)	The owner shall operate and maintain the private wastewater disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the city. 
(Code 1988, § 6-3-4)
Sec. 98-133. - Water not to be furnished to premises with improper sewage disposal. 
No city water shall be furnished to any premises which is required to be connected to the city sewerage system unless such premises is properly connected thereto. No water shall be furnished to any premises for which a sewer connection is not required unless such premises is properly connected to a permitted septic tank or private wastewater disposal system meeting the standards prescribed by the state, county and city. 
(Code 1988, § 6-3-5)
Sec. 98-134. - Building sewers and connections. 
(a)	No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the designated city representative. 
(b)	No unauthorized person shall remove covers, deface, destroy, disturb, cover or enter any manholes of the public sewer system without permission from an authorized representative of the city. 
(c)	There shall be two classes of building sewer permits: (i) For residential and commercial service; and (ii) for service to establishments producing industrial wastes. In either case, the owner or his agent shall make application on a special form furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications or other information considered pertinent in the judgement of the designated city representative. A permit and inspection fee for a residential or commercial building sewer permit and a permit and inspection fee for an industrial building sewer permit shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. 
(d)	All costs and expenses incidental to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(e)	A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building; except where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway, the front building sewer may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as the one building sewer, but the city does not and will not assume any obligation or responsibility for damage caused by or resulting from any such single connection as provided in this subsection. 
(f)	Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the designated city representative, to meet all requirements of this article. 
(g)	The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing and backfilling the trench, shall all conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. In the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the Standard Plumbing Code shall apply. 
(h)	Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer. 
(i)	No unauthorized person shall construct any structure or other facility on or perform any grading or substantially disturb the ground on a sewer easement or right-of-way of the city without submitting a written request to and obtaining approval of the city. Plans for such an encroachment may be required. 
(j)	No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, foundation drains, areaway drains, swimming pool drains or other sources of surface runoff, groundwater or other unpolluted water to a building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. 
(k)	No person shall install, extend, connect, alter or enlarge any wastewater facilities unless plans and specifications are prepared by a qualified person as required by law and such plans and specifications are approved by the authorized representative of the city and the state department of natural resources, environmental protection division. 
(l)	The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city, or the procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the Standard Building Code. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight and verified by proper testing. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the designated city representative before installation. 
(m)	The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the designated city representative when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection and testing shall be made under the supervision of the designated city representative. 
(n)	All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, alleys, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. 
(o)	The installation of all building sewers and connections into the public sewer shall conform with all pertinent OSHA requirements. 
(Code 1988, § 6-3-6)
Sec. 98-135. - Use of the public sewers. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any user to discharge any wastewater to the POTW except as authorized by the designated city representative in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)	No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged into the POTW any unpolluted waters such as stormwater, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, unpolluted industrial process water or uncontaminated cooling water to any sewer, except stormwater runoff from limited areas, which stormwater may be polluted at times and may be discharged to the sanitary sewer by written permission of the designated city representative. 
(c)	Stormwater other than that exempted under subsection (b) of this section and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as storm sewers or to a natural outlet approved by the designated city representative and other regulatory agencies. Unpolluted industrial cooling water or process waters may be discharged, on approval of the designated city representative and the EPD to a storm sewer or natural outlet. 
(d)	Pollutants introduced into the POTW by a nondomestic source shall not pass through the POTW or interfere with the operation or performance of the works. These general prohibitions apply to all users of the POTW whether or not the user is subject to national categorical pretreatment standards or any other national, state, or local pretreatment standards or requirements. 
(e)	No person shall introduce into the POTW any of the following pollutants which, acting either alone or in conjunction with other substances, interfere with the operation or performance of the POTWs: 
(1)	Any liquids, solids or gases which by reason of their nature or quantity are, or may be, sufficient either alone or by interaction with other substances to cause fire or explosion or be injurious in any other way to the POTW or to the operation of the POTW. At no time shall two successive readings on an explosion hazard meter, at the point of discharge into the system (or at any point in the system) be more than five percent nor any single reading over ten percent of the lower explosive limit (LEL) of the meter. Prohibited materials include, but are not limited to, gasoline, kerosene, naphtha, benzene, toluene, xylene, ethers, alcohols, ketones, aldehydes, peroxides, chlorates, perchlorates, bromates, carbides, hydrides and sulfides and any other substances which the city, EPD or EPA has notified the user is a fire hazard or a hazard to the system. 
(2)	Any wastewaters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or higher than 9.5 at any time, or having any corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment and personnel of the water pollution control facilities. 
(3)	Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other interference with the proper operation of the wastewater facilities such as, but not limited to, ashes, bones, cinders, spent lime, stone or marble dust, sand, mud, grass clippings, spent grains, spent hops, straw, shavings, metal, glass, glass grindings or polishing wastes, rags, feathers, gas, asphalt residues, residues from refining or processing of fuel or lubricating oil, tar, plastics, paint or ink residues, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, animal guts or tissues, hair and fleshings, entrails, offal, paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either whole or ground by garbage grinders. 
(f)	The following described substances, materials, waters or waste shall be limited in discharge to the municipal system to concentrations or quantities which will not, either singly or by interaction with other pollutants, harm either the sewers, wastewater treatment process or equipment, will not have an adverse effect on the receiving stream or land application field or will not otherwise endanger lives, limbs, public property, or constitute a nuisance. The designated city representative may set limitations lower than the limitations established in the regulations in this subsection if in his opinion such more severe limitations are necessary to meet the objectives of this subsection. In forming his opinion as to the acceptability of a discharge, the designated city representative will give consideration to such factors as the quantity of subject waste in relation to flows and velocities in the sewers, materials of construction of the sewers, the wastewater treatment process employed, capacity of the wastewater treatment plant, degree of treatability of the waste in the wastewater treatment plant and other pertinent factors. The limitations or restrictions on materials or characteristics of waste or wastewaters discharged to the sanitary sewer which shall not be violated without approval of the designated city representative are as follows: 
(1)	Any substance which will cause the POTW to violate its NPDES and/or LAS and/or state disposal system permit and/or the receiving waters quality standards and/or the discharge requirements to the land application field. 
(2)	Wastewater having a temperature higher than 150 degree Fahrenheit or that would raise wastewater treatment works influent temperature above 104 degrees Fahrenheit. 
(3)	Any water or waste containing fats, wax, grease or oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of 100 mg/l. 
(4)	Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. Garbage grinders may be connected to sanitary sewers from homes, hotels, institutions, restaurants, hospitals, catering establishments, or similar places where garbage originates from the preparation of food in kitchens for the purpose of consumption on the premises or when served by caterers. 
(5)	Any waters or wastes containing heavy metals and similar objectionable or toxic substances to such degree that any such material at the point of discharge exceeds the limits established as follows: 

 
Or any element which in the judgement of the designated city representative, will damage collection facilities or be detrimental to the treatment process. The limits set forth in this subsection may be amended if such amendment is deemed necessary to protect the facilities or life or health and/or to comply with applicable state or federal regulations. 
(6)	Any noxious or malodorous liquid, gas or solid, capable of creating a public nuisance or hazard to life or preventing entry of workmen into the POTW for maintenance, inspection and repair. 
(7)	Any waters containing quantities of radioactive wastes or isotopes in excess of applicable state or federal regulations or permits issued by state or federal agencies. 
(8)	Any concentrated dye wastes, spent tanning solutions or other wastes which are highly colored. 
(9)	Any water or wastes that contain more than ten parts per million, by weight, of the following gases: hydrogen sulfide, sulphur dioxide or nitrous oxide. 
(10)	Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by the wastewater treatment processes employed, or are amenable to treatment only to such degree that the wastewater treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters or land application site. 
(11)	Any water or wastes which, by interaction with other water or wastes in the public sewer system, release obnoxious gases, form suspended solids which interfere with the collection system, or create a condition deleterious to structures and treatment processes. 
(12)	Any pollutants, including oxygen demanding pollutants (BOD, etc.) released at a flow rate and/or pollutant concentration which a user knows or has reason to know will cause interference to the POTW. Any water or waste having a five-day biochemical oxygen demand greater than 500 mg/l or containing more than 500 mg/l of suspended solids is prohibited. Sewer use surcharges will be applied for discharges having a five-day biochemical oxygen demand greater than 250 mg/l containing more than 250 mg/l of suspended solids. In no case shall a slug load have a flow rate or contain concentrated or quantities of pollutants that exceed for any time period longer than 15 minutes more than five times the average 24-hour concentration, quantities or flow during normal operation. Where, in the opinion of the designated city representative, the biochemical oxygen demand does not provide meaningful measurements of wastewater strength, the city representative may substitute chemical oxygen demand limits of 500 mg/l for application of surcharges and 1,000 mg/l for prohibition of wastes, in lieu of the BOD limits. 
(13)	Any waters having ammonia nitrogen concentrations greater than 100 mg/l are prohibited. Sewer use surcharges will be applied for discharges having ammonia nitrogen concentrations in excess of 50 mg/l. 
(14)	Any substance which will interfere with the reclamation or reuse of residues, sludges or scums. If a substance discharged to the POTW cause the POTW to be in noncompliance with sludge use or disposal criteria under Section 405 of the Act, the Solid Waste Disposal Act, the Clean Air Act, the Toxic Substances Control Act or state criteria applicable to sludge management. 
(15)	Any slug load, in accordance with subsection (f)(12) of this section, discharged to the POTW unless specifically authorized, in writing, as part of the user's discharge permit. 
(g)	If any waters or wastes are discharged or are proposed to be discharged to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in this section and which in the judgement of the designated city representative may have a deleterious effect upon the wastewater facilities, processes, equipment, receiving waters, or land application site or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the designated city representative shall advise the user of the impact of the contribution on the POTW, and develop effluent limitations for such user to correct the interference with the POTW. The designated city representative may also: 
(1)	Reject the wastes;
(2)	Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers;
(3)	Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or
(4)	Require payment to cover added cost of handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges. 
(h)	If the designated city representative permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the design and installation of the plant and equipment shall be subject to the review and approval of the designated city representative. Dilution of incompatible wastes with uncontaminated water is not an acceptable method of waste equalization. 
(i)	Grit traps shall be provided on all commercial and industrial discharges containing potentially excessive amounts of sand, grit, ash or other harmful solids. All grit traps shall be of a type and capacity approved by the designated city representative, and shall be located so as to be readily accessible for cleaning and inspection.
